revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1524|literature}} This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1524'''.
==Events== * ''Eyn Gespräch von dem gemaynen Schwabacher Kasten'' ("als durch Brüder Hainrich, Knecht Ruprecht, Kemerin, Spüler, und irem Maister, des Handtwercks der Wüllen Tuchmacher") is published in Germany, the first publication in the "[[Schwabacher]]" [[blackletter]] [[typeface]].
==New books== *[[Petrus Apianus]] – ''Cosmographicus liber'' ([[Landshut]]) *[[Philippe de Commines]] – ''Mémoires'' (Part 1: Books 1–6; first publication; [[Paris]]) *[[Desiderius Erasmus]] – ''[[De libero arbitrio diatribe sive collatio]]'' ("The Freedom of the Will"; [[Antwerp]], September) *[[Martin Luther]] and [[Paul Speratus]] – ''Etlich Cristlich Lider: Lobgesang un Psalm'' ("Achtliederbuch"), the [[first Lutheran hymnal]] ([[Wittenberg]]) *Martin Luther and others – ''Eyn Enchiridion oder Handbüchlein'' (the "[[Erfurt Enchiridion]]"), two editions of a [[hymnal]] printed respectively by [[Johannes Loersfeld]] and Matthes Maler ([[Erfurt]]), including Luther's [[hymn]] "[[Christ lag in Todes Banden]]" *[[Adam Ries]] – ''Coß'' *[[Johann Walter]] – ''[[Eyn geystlich Gesangk Buchleyn]]'' ("A sacred little hymnal") (Wittenberg), including Luther's chorale "[[Gelobet seist du, Jesu Christ]]"
==New poetry== {{main|1524 in poetry}} *[[Robert Copland]] – ''Epilogue to the Syege of Rodes'' (London)
==New drama== *[[Ludovico Ariosto]] – ''I suppositi'' ([[1509 in literature|1509]], first publication, in prose) *[[Niklaus Manuel Deutsch I]] – ''Vom Papst und seiner Priesterschaft''
==Births== * [[May 28]] – [[Selim II]], Ottoman Turkish sultan and poet (died [[1574 in literature|1574]]) * [[September 11]] – [[Pierre de Ronsard]], French poet (died [[1585 in literature|1585]]) * ''Unknown date'' – [[Thomas Tusser]], English agriculturalist, poet and chorister (died [[1580 in literature|1580]]) * ''Approximate year of birth'' ** [[Luís de Camões]], Portuguese national poet (died [[1580 in literature|1580]]) ** [[Girolamo Parabosco]], Italian poet and musician (died [[1577 in literature|1577]])
==Deaths== * [[January 5]] – [[Marko Marulić]] of [[Split, Croatia|Split]], Croatian Christian humanist and poet (born [[1450 in literature|1450]]) * [[January 7]] (or 1523) – [[Tang Yin]] (唐寅, also Tang Bohu, 唐伯), Chinese scholar, poet and calligrapher (born [[1470 in literature|1470]]) * [[Giovanni Aurelio Augurello]], Italian humanist scholar and alchemist writing [[Latin]] poetry (born [[1456 in literature|1456]])
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1524 In Literature}} [[Category:1524]] [[Category:1524 books]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 16th century in literature]]

revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1736|literature|poetry}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1736'''.
==Events== *[[Charles Rivington]] founds a company of London booksellers known as the ''New Conger''.<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Rivington, Charles|volume=48}}</ref>
==New books== ===Prose=== *Anonymous – ''The Life of Marianne'' (fiction, translation of [[Pierre Carlet de Chamblain de Marivaux]]) *[[Joseph Addison]] – ''The Works of Petronius Arbiter'' (translation) *[[John Armstrong (poet)|John Armstrong]] – ''The Oeconomy of Love'' *[[Thomas Bayes]] – ''An Introduction to the Doctrine of Fluxions, and a Defence of the Mathematicians Against the Objections of the Author of the Analyst'' *[[Isaac Hawkins Browne (poet)|Isaac Hawkins Browne]] – ''A Pipe of Tobacco'' *[[Joseph Butler]] – ''Analogy of Religion'' *[[Thomas Carte]] – ''Life of [[James Butler, 1st Duke of Ormonde|James Duke of Ormonde]]'' *[[William Rufus Chetwood]] – ''The Voyages. . . of William Owen Gwin Vaughan'' *[[Eliza Haywood]] – ''Adventures of Eovaai'' (later as ''The Unfortunate Princess'') *[[Muhammad ibn Abd-al-Wahhab]] – ''Kitab at-tawhidt'' *[[Isaac Newton]] – ''[[Method of Fluxions]]'' *[[Elizabeth Rowe]] – ''The History of Joseph'' *[[William Stukeley]] – ''Palaeographia Sacra'' *[[James Thomson (poet)|James Thomson]] – ''Britain'' *[[William Warburton]] – ''The Alliance Between Church and State'' (an answer to Benjamin Hoadly from the [[1735 in literature|year before]]) *[[Leonard Welsted]] – ''The Scheme and Conduct of Providence'' *[[Diego de Torres Villarroel]] **''Los desahuciados del mundo y de la gloria'' (The Deathly Illness of the World and of Glory) **''Historia de historias''
===Drama=== *[[Henry Carey (writer)|Henry Carey]] – ''The Honest Yorkshireman'' *[[Colley Cibber]] – ''Papal Tyranny in the Reign of King John'' *[[Henry Fielding]] – ''[[Pasquin]]'' *[[Aaron Hill (writer)|Aaron Hill]] – ''Alzira'' *[[George Lillo]] – ''The Fatal Curiosity'' *[[James Miller (playwright)|James Miller]] – ''The Man of Taste''
===Poems=== *[[Stephen Duck]] – ''Poems on Several Occasions'' *[[William Melmoth]] – ''Two Epistles of Horace Imitated'' *[[Alexander Pope]] – ''The Works of Alexander Pope'' vols iii–iv *[[Voltaire]] – ''[[Le Mondain]]''
==Births== *[[May 10]] – [[George Steevens]], English Shakespearean editor and hoaxer (died [[1800 in literature|1800]]) *[[June 25]] – [[John Horne Tooke]], English controversialist and cleric (died [[1812 in literature|1812]]) *[[October 27]] – [[James Macpherson]], Scottish writer, poet and politician (died [[1796 in literature|1796]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Robert Jephson]], Irish dramatist and politician (died [[1803 in literature|1803]]) **[[James Ridley]] (Sir Charles Morell), English novelist and story writer (died [[1765 in literature|1765]])
==Deaths== *[[February 9]] – [[Barnaby Bernard Lintot]], English bookseller and publisher (born [[1675 in literature|1675]]) *[[March 18]] – [[Jacob Tonson]], English bookseller and publisher (born c. 1655) *[[April 30]] – [[Johann Albert Fabricius]], German scholar and bibliographer (born [[1668 in literature|1668]]) *[[July 16]] – [[Thomas Yalden]], English poet and translator (born [[1670 in literature|1670]])
==In literature== *[[John Fowles]]' novel ''[[A Maggot]]'' ([[1985 in literature|1985]]) opens this May. *[[Walter Scott]]'s novel ''[[The Heart of Midlothian]]'' ([[1818 in literature|1818]]) is set during the [[Porteous Riots]].
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authoritycontrol}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1736 In Literature}} [[Category:1736 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 18th century in literature]]

revision.comment: adding link to rocaille style
revision.text:
{{French art history}} '''18th-century French art''' was dominated by the [[Baroque]], [[Rocaille]] and [[Neoclassicism in France|neoclassical]] movements.
==History<!--'French neoclassicism' and 'French Neoclassicism' redirct here-->== In France, the death of [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]] in September 1715 led to a period of licentious freedom commonly called the [[Régence]]. The heir to Louis XIV, his great grandson [[Louis XV of France]], was only 5 years old; for the next seven years France was ruled by the regent [[Philippe II of Orléans]]. Versailles was abandoned from 1715 to 1722. Painting turned toward "fêtes galantes", theater settings and the female nude. Painters from this period include [[Antoine Watteau]], [[Nicolas Lancret]] and [[François Boucher]]. One of the best places in the UK to see examples of French visual and decorative arts of the Rococo and neoclassical periods is in [[Wallace Collection|the Wallace Collection]], a free national gallery in London.
The [[Louis XV style]] of decoration (although already apparent at the end of the last reign) was lighter: pastels and wood panels, smaller rooms, less gilding and fewer brocades; shells and garlands and occasional Chinese subjects predominated. Rooms were more intimate. After the return to Versailles, many of the baroque rooms of Louis XIV were redesigned. The official etiquette was also simplified and the notion of privacy was expanded: the king himself retreated from the official bed at night and conversed in private with his mistress.
The latter half of the 18th century continued to see French preeminence in Europe, particularly through the arts and sciences, and the [[French language]] was the lingua franca of the European courts. The French academic system continued to produce artists, but some, like [[Jean-Honoré Fragonard]] and [[Jean-Baptiste-Siméon Chardin]], explored new and increasingly impressionist styles of painting with thick brushwork. Although the hierarchy of genres continued to be respected officially, [[Genre works|genre painting]], [[Landscape art|landscape]], [[portrait]] and [[still life]] were extremely fashionable.
The writer [[Denis Diderot]] wrote a number of times on the annual [[Paris Salon|Salons]] of the Académie of painting and sculpture and his comments and criticisms are a vital document on the arts of this period.
One of Diderot's favorite painters was [[Jean-Baptiste Greuze]]. Although often considered [[kitsch]] by today's standards, his paintings of domestic scenes reveal the importance of [[Sentimentality|Sentimentalism]] in the European arts of the period (as also seen in the works of [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]] and [[Samuel Richardson]].)
One also finds in this period a kind of ''[[Pre-romanticism]]''. [[Hubert Robert]]'s images of ruins, inspired by Italian cappricio paintings, are typical in this respect. So too the change from the rational and geometrical ''French garden'' (of [[André Le Nôtre]]) to the ''English garden'', which emphasized (artificially) wild and irrational nature. One also finds in some of these gardens curious ruins of temples called [[Folly|follies]].
The middle of the 18th century saw a turn to [[Neoclassicism]] in France, that is to say a conscious use of Greek and Roman forms and iconography. In painting, the greatest representative of this style is [[Jacques-Louis David]] who, mirroring the profiles of Greek vases, emphasized the use of the profile; his subject matter often involved classical history (the death of Socrates, Brutus). The dignity and subject matter of his paintings were greatly inspired by [[Nicolas Poussin]] in the 17th century.
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Jacob4Chairs.jpg|left|thumb|300px|A suite of Louis XVI giltwood chairs made circa 1775 by [[Georges Jacob]].]] -->
The [[Louis XVI style]] of furniture (once again already present in the previous reign) tended toward circles and ovals in chair backs; chair legs were grooved; Greek inspired iconography was used as decoration.
'''French neoclassicism'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA--> would greatly contribute to the monumentalism of the [[French revolution]], as typified in the structures [[Eglise de la Madeleine|La Madeleine]] church (begun in 1763 and finished in 1840) which is in the form of a [[Greek temple]] and the mammoth [[Panthéon]] (1764–1812) which today houses the tombs of great Frenchmen. The rationalism and simplicity of classical architecture was seen — in the [[Age of Enlightenment]] — as the antithesis of the backward-looking [[Gothic art|Gothic]].
The Greek and Roman subject matters were also often chosen to promote the values of republicanism. One also finds paintings glorifying the heroes and martyrs of the French revolution, such as David's painting of the assassination of [[Jean-Paul Marat]].
[[Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres]], a student of David's who was also influenced by [[Raphael]] and [[John Flaxman]], would maintain the precision of David's style, while also exploring other mythological (Oedipus and the sphinx, Jupiter and Thetis) and oriental (the Odalesques) subjects in the spirit of [[Romanticism]].
==See also== * [[Neoclassicism in France]] * [[French neoclassical theatre]] * [[List of French artists#Eighteenth century|List of French artists of the eighteenth century]] * [[Louis XV style]] * [[Louis XVI style]] * [[Louis XV furniture]] * [[Louis XVI furniture]]
==References== *André Chastel. ''French Art Vol III: The Ancient Régime'' {{ISBN|2-08-013617-8}}
[[Category:French art]] [[Category:Neoclassical architecture in France| ]] [[Category:18th century in France|Art]]

revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|2013|art}} The year '''2013 in art''' involves some significant events.
==Events== * [[March 9]] – The identification of ''[[Portrait of Olivia Boteler Porter]]'' as an original work of the 1630s by Sir [[Anthony van Dyck]] is announced. It is in the collection of the [[Bowes Museum]], [[County Durham]], England.<ref>{{cite news|title=Van Dyck painting 'found online'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-21712209|accessdate=2013-03-18|work=[[BBC News]]|date=2013-03-09}}</ref> [[File:Olivia Boteler Porter before and after restoration.jpg|thumb|''Portrait of Olivia Boteler Porter'' by Anthony van Dyck before and after restoration. The version on the left was the photograph originally posted to the Your Paintings website.]] * [[March 18]] – The identification of ''[[Self-portrait wearing a white feathered bonnet]]'' as an original work of [[1635 in art|1635]] by [[Rembrandt]] is announced. Hanging in [[Buckland Abbey]], [[Devon]], England, it is the only painting by this artist in the collection of the British [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty]] to whom it was gifted in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Expert confirms painting is a Rembrandt |url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/article-1355774862560/ |publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] |location=Swindon |date=2013-03-18 |accessdate=2013-03-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130321055502/http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/article-1355774862560/ |archivedate=2013-03-21 |df= }}</ref> * April – The philanthropist and art collector [[Leonard Lauder]] promises for donation his important collection of [[Cubist]] works by artists including [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Georges Braque]] and [[Juan Gris]] estimated to be valued at over one billion US dollars to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in [[New York City, New York]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/10/arts/design/leonard-lauder-is-giving-his-cubist-collection-to-the-met.html|title=Leonard Lauder Is Giving His Cubist Collection to the Met|first=Carol|last=Vogel|date=9 April 2013|publisher=|access-date=16 October 2017|via=www.NYTimes.com}}</ref> * [[April 13]] – The [[Rijksmuseum]] in Amsterdam is re-opened by Queen [[Beatrix of the Netherlands]] after a ten-year refurbishment.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22024351 Rijksmuseum set for grand reopening in Amsterdam], [[BBC News]], 4 April 2013. Retrieved on 2013-04-04.</ref> * May – Extension to [[Lenbachhaus]] art museum, designed by [[Foster and Partners]], is opened in [[Munich]]. * [[May 9]] – [[Charles Ray (artist)|Charles Ray]]'s sculpture "[[Boy with Frog]]" is removed by the city of Venice from where it stood before the Punta della Dogana overlooking where the [[Grand Canal (Venice)|Grand Canal]] meets the [[Giudecca Canal]]. The work which had been commissioned by [[Francois-Henri Pinault]] to stand outside the aforementioned historic building which serves as an annex to his main museum housed in the [[Palazzo Grassi]] was replaced by a contemporary copy of a streetlamp which once stood at the same spot.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ignacio Villarreal |url=http://artdaily.com/index.asp?int_sec=2&int_new=62452 |title=Venice removes controversial Boy with Frog statue by American artist Charles Ray |publisher=Artdaily.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> * July–October – [[Gromit Unleashed]] in [[Bristol]], England.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mathias|first1=Vicki|title=Gromit Unleashed: Now we're all going "Gromiting"|url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Gromit-Unleashed-going-Gromiting/story-19498599-detail/story.html#axzz2aQxy4yJM|accessdate=2013-07-29|work=This is Bristol|date=2013-07-10|last2=Beard|first2=George|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130715043606/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/Gromit-Unleashed-going-Gromiting/story-19498599-detail/story.html#axzz2aQxy4yJM|archive-date=2013-07-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *[[July 14]] – The dedication of the [[Rachel Carson (sculpture)|''Rachel Carson'']] in [[Woods Hole, Massachusetts]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nefsc.noaa.gov/news/features/rachel_carson/|title=Unveiling and Dedication of the Rachel Carson Statue|last=|first=|date=2013-07-30|website=Northeast Fisheries Science Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|language=en|access-date=2018-09-20}}</ref> * [[July 25]] – [[Katharina Fritsch]]'s sculpture ''Hahn/Cock'' is unveiled on the [[fourth plinth, Trafalgar Square]], London.<ref>{{citation|title=Katharina Fritsch on her Fourth Plinth cockerel sculpture: 'I didn't want to make fun – but I was invited'|first=Laura|last=Barnett|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|date=2013-07-24|accessdate=2013-07-25|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2013/jul/24/katharina-fritsch-fourth-plinth-cockerel-sculpture}}</ref> *[[October]] - The English street artist [[Banksy]] stages an entire month of daily public instillations all over New York City entitled "[[Better Out Than In]]".<ref>http://www.villagevoice.com/microsites/banksy-nyc/</ref> [[File:Banksy 15 October installment in Better Out Than In New York City residency.jpg|thumb|right|Flowers left at Banksy's depiction of the former [[World Trade Center (1973-2001)|World Trade Center]] in [[TriBeCa]]]] * [[October 21]] - [[Cleveland Museum of Art]] director [[David Franklin (curator)|David Franklin]] resigns citing personal reasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/arts/index.ssf/2013/10/cleveland_museum_of_art_direct_1.html|title=Cleveland Museum of Art Director David Franklin resigns for personal reasons, effective immediately|author=|date=|website=Cleveland.com|access-date=16 October 2017}}</ref> Numerous published sources later revealed that the married Franklin had been involved in an affair with a subordinate. When this revelation came to the attention of the board, Franklin chose to leave.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clevescene.com/scene-and-heard/archives/2013/10/23/former-cleveland-museum-of-art-director-david-franklin-resigns-after-affair-suicide-cell-phone-of-victim-missing|title=Former Cleveland Museum of Art Director David Franklin Resigns After Affair, Suicide; Cell Phone of Victim Missing|first=Vince|last=Grzegorek|date=|website=CleveScene.com|access-date=16 October 2017}}</ref> The woman in question, Christina Gaston, committed suicide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/arts/index.ssf/2013/11/investigation_remains_closed_i.html|title=Investigation remains closed in the suicide of the lover of Cleveland Museum of Art director David Franklin, but questions linger|author=|date=|website=Cleveland.com|access-date=16 October 2017}}</ref> * [[November 3]] – The magazine ''[[Focus (German magazine)|Focus]]'' reveals that in March 2012, 121 framed and 1,258 unframed artworks were discovered by [[Bundeszollverwaltung|German customs authorities]] in an apartment in [[Schwabing]], [[Munich]]. Seized from the possession of [[Cornelius Gurlitt (art collector)|Cornelius Gurlitt]], son of 1930s and later [[degenerate art]] dealer [[Hildebrand Gurlitt]], the cache includes works by [[Marc Chagall]], [[Henri Matisse]], [[Otto Dix]] and others.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hickley|first=Catherine|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-11-11/german-government-to-speed-up-research-on-munich-cache.html|title=Germany Says 590 Artworks in Munich Haul May Be Nazi Loot|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2013-11-11|accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> * [[November 12]] – The triptych ''[[Three Studies of Lucian Freud]]'' by the painter [[Francis Bacon (painter)|Francis Bacon]] sells for {{USD|link=yes}}142.4 million (including the buyer's premium) to an unnamed buyer at [[Christie's]] New York auction house, becoming [[List of most expensive paintings|the most expensive work of art ever to be sold at auction]].<ref name="NYT Scream">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/03/arts/design/the-scream-sells-for-nearly-120-million-at-sothebys-auction.html|title={{-'}}''The Scream''{{'}} Is Auctioned for a Record $119.9 Million|last=Vogel|first=Carol|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2 May 2012|accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref> The 2013 sale also represents the highest price paid for a work by a British artist, beating Bacon's ''[[Triptych, 1976|Triptych 1976]]'', which fetched $86.3 million in May 2008.<ref name="NYT Triptych 1976">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/15/arts/design/15auction.html|title=Bacon Triptych Auctioned for Record $86 Million|last=Vogel|first=Carol|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 May 2008|access-date=13 November 2013}}</ref> * [[November 19]] – Museo Júmex in [[Mexico City]], designed by [[David Chipperfield]], is opened to show part of the contemporary art [[Colección Júmex]]. * [[November 20]] - The "[[Graffiti]] Mecca" [[5Pointz]] on the sides of a twentieth-century warehouse in [[Long Island City]], [[Queens, New York]], is whitewashed by a team of painters in the employ of the site's new developers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/chase-guttman/five-pointz_b_4317468.html|title=Rest in Peace, Five Pointz|first=Chase|last=Guttman|date=21 November 2013|website=HuffingtonPost.com|access-date=16 October 2017}}</ref> * [[November 25]] – "The Church of Vezzoli", the [[MoMA PS1|PS1]], New York City leg of Italian artist [[Francesco Vezzoli]]'s three part retrospective, "The Trinity", is cancelled after the church he arranged to buy in the town of [[Montegiordano]] for deployment in the exhibition is remanded in Italy prior to its leaving the country for the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/26/arts/design/francesco-vezzolis-art-show-hits-a-snag.html|title=Francesco Vezzoli’s Art Show Hits a Snag|first1=Ted|last1=Loos|first2=Gaia|last2=Pianigiani|date=25 November 2013|publisher=|access-date=16 October 2017|via=www.NYTimes.com}}</ref> * [[November 28]] – [[The Tetley (Leeds)]] opens as a [[contemporary art]] [[Art gallery|gallery]] in England. * [[December 4]] – [[Pérez Art Museum Miami]], designed by [[Herzog & de Meuron]], is opened.<ref>{{cite news|first=Caroline|last=Roux|date=2013-11-29|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/360d7b96-5363-11e3-b425-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2m8Xym042|title=Architect Christine Binswanger on Pérez Art Museum Miami|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|location=London|accessdate=2013-12-29}}</ref> * [[December 12]] – From today until March 16, 2014 the [[Dying Galatian|Dying Gaul]] is put on display in the main rotunda of the west wing of the [[National Gallery of Art]] in [[Washington D.C.]] This temporary tenure marks the first time the antiquity has left [[Italy]] since it was returned in the second decade of the nineteenth century after Napoleon brought it to [[the Louvre]] in 1797 as a plunder of war.
==Exhibitions== *[[February 1]] until [[May 6]] – "[[Carl Andre]]: Mass & Matter" at the [[Turner Contemporary]], [[Margate]], [[England]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Alastair|last=Sooke|title=Carl Andre: Mass & Matter, Turner Contemporary, Margate, review|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-reviews/9832202/Carl-Andre-Mass-and-Matter-Turner-Contemporary-Margate-review.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|date=2013-01-28|accessdate=2013-02-01}}</ref> *[[February 3]] until [[May 9]] – "[[Llyn Foulkes]]" at the [[Hammer Museum]] at [[UCLA]] in [[Los Angeles, California]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/feb/07/entertainment/la-et-cm-0207-knight-foulkes-review-20130207|first=Christopher|last=Knight|title=Art review: Retrospective shows Llyn Foulkes' sharp eccentricity|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2013-02-07|accessdate=2013-03-18}}</ref> *[[February 15]] until [[May 8]] – "[[Gutai]]: Splendid Playground" at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Roberta|last=Smith|title=The Seriousness of Fun in Postwar Japan‘Gutai: Splendid Playground’ at the Guggenheim|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/15/arts/design/gutai-splendid-playground-at-the-guggenheim.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2013-02-14|accessdate=2013-03-04}}</ref> *[[March 5]] until [[May 27]] – "Street" by [[James Nares (artist)|James Nares]] at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York City<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/12/nyregion/in-james-naress-street-taming-the-galloping-city.html|title=In James Nares’s ‘STREET,’ Taming the Galloping City|first=Martha|last=Schwendener|date=10 August 2012|publisher=|access-date=16 October 2017|via=www.NYTimes.com}}</ref> *[[March 16]] until [[June 16]] – [[Karl Stirner]] "Transformations II: Works in Steel" at the [[Michener Art Museum]] in [[Doylestown, Pennsylvania]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michenermuseum.org/exhibition/transformations-ii-works-in-steel-by-karl-stirner |title=Transformations II: Works in Steel by Karl Stirner - Michener Art Museum |publisher=Michenermuseum.org |date=2013-06-16 |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[March 23]] - [[August 11]] - "[[David Bowie]] is" at the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in [[London]], England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/exhibitions/david-bowie-is/about-the-exhibition|title=David Bowie is: About the Exhibition|first=Victoria and Albert Museum, Digital Media|last=webmaster@vam.ac.uk|date=|website=www.VAM.ac.uk|access-date=16 October 2017}}</ref> *[[May 3]] until [[September 29]] – "[[Jack Goldstein]] x 10,000" at the [[Jewish Museum (Manhattan)|Jewish Museum]] in New York City, New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejewishmuseum.org/exhibitions/jack-goldstein |title=The Jewish Museum New York | Art Exhibition | JACK GOLDSTEIN × 10,000 |publisher=Thejewishmuseum.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225080953/http://www.thejewishmuseum.org/exhibitions/jack-goldstein |archive-date=2013-12-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[May 12]] until [[October 6]] – "[[Sergei Diaghilev|Diaghilev]] and the [[Ballets Russes]], 1909–1929: When Art Danced with Music" at the [[National Gallery of Art]], in [[Washington D.C.]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/exhibitions/2013/diaghilev.html |title=Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes, 1909-1929: When Art Danced with Music |publisher=Nga.gov |date=2013-10-06 |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[May 23]] until October 6 – "[[Edward Hopper|Hopper]] Drawing at the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]] in New York City, New York.<ref>{{cite |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[May 29]] until [[November 24]] – "Galleria Vezzoli" by [[Francesco Vezzoli]] at [[MAXXI]] in [[Rome, Italy]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Ignacio Villarreal |url=http://artdaily.com/news/62907/Galleria-Vezzoli-at-Maxxi--Over-90-works-in-the-first-Italian-retrospective-devoted-to-Francesco-Vezzoli |title=Galleria Vezzoli at Maxxi: Over 90 works in the first Italian retrospective devoted to Francesco Vezzoli |publisher=Artdaily.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[June 1]] until [[October 27]] – [[Sir Anthony Caro]] at the [[Museo Correr]], [[Venice, Italy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://correr.visitmuve.it/en/mostre-en/mostre-in-corso-en/caro-at-correr/2013/02/9194/exhibition-3/ |title=Museo Correr | Exhibition |publisher=Correr.visitmuve.it |date=2013-10-27 |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[June 21]] until [[September 25]] – "[[James Turrell]]: Video Transcript at the Solomon R. "[[Richard Diebenkorn]]: The [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]] Years, 1953-1966" at the [[de Young Museum]] in [[San Francisco, California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deyoung.famsf.org/press-room/richard-diebenkorn-berkeley-years-1953-1966|title=Richard Diebenkorn: The Berkeley Years, 1953–1966|author=|date=14 May 2013|website=FAMSF.org|access-date=16 October 2017}}</ref> *[[August 3]] until [[November 3]] – [[Peter Doig]]: "No Foreign Lands" at the [[Scottish National Gallery]], [[Edinburgh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalgalleries.org/whatson/exhibitions/peter-doig/ |title=Peter Doig − Past − What's On − National Galleries of Scotland |publisher=Nationalgalleries.org |date=2013-11-03 |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[August 10]] until [[November 3]] – "Soundings: A Contemporary Score", at the [[Museum of Modern Art]], [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/exhibitions/1379 |title=Soundings: A Contemporary Score |publisher=MoMA |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[August 17]] - Hammer Museum|author=|date=|website=The Hammer Museum|access-date=16 October 2017}}</ref> *[[September 22]] until January 4, 2014 – "[[Mark Milloff|Milloff's]] [[Herman Melville|Melville]]" at the [[Lyman Allyn Art Museum]] in [[New London, Connecticut]] <ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.lymanallyn.org/milloffs-melville/ |title=Milloff’s Melville |publisher=Lymanallyn.org |date=2013-07-23 |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[September 26]] until January 4, 2014 – "[[Robert Indiana]]: Beyond [[Love (sculpture)|LOVE]]" at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York City, New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/RobertIndiana |title=Whitney Museum of American Art: Robert Indiana: Beyond LOVE |publisher=Whitney.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[September 28]], 2013 until January 6, 2014 – "The Avant-Gardes of Fin-de-Siècle Paris" at the [[Peggy Guggenheim Collection]] in [[Venice, Italy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guggenheim.org/venice/exhibitions/the-avant-gardes-of-fin-de-siecle-paris |title=The Avant-Gardes of Fin-de-Siècle Paris |publisher=Guggenheim.org |date=2013-09-28 |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[October 2]] until January 14, 2014 – "[[Chris Burden]]: Extreme Measures" at the [[New Museum]] of Contemporary Art in New York City, New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newmuseum.org/exhibitions/view/chris-burden-extreme-measures |title=Chris Burden: Extreme Measures |publisher=New Museum |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[October 4]] until January 26, 2014 – "[[Harry Holtzman]] and American Abstraction" at the [[Florence Griswold Museum]] in [[Old Lyme, Connecticut]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.florencegriswoldmuseum.org/exhibitions_13Holtzman.php |title=Home of American Impressionism. Visit where the Lyme Art Colony in Old Lyme Connecticut once lived |publisher=Florence Griswold Museum |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[October 5]] until March 16, 2014 – The [[Carnegie International]] at the [[Carnegie Museum of Art]] in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ci13.cmoa.org |title=2013 Carnegie International |publisher=Ci13.cmoa.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-24}}</ref> *[[October 23]] until March - “Damage Control: Art and Destruction SINCE 1950" at the [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]] in [[Washington D.C.]] *[[October 24]] until May 26, 2014 - [[Christopher Wool]] at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City, New York.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/exhibitions/on-view/christopher-wool |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-12-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109055259/http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/exhibitions/on-view/christopher-wool |archive-date=2014-01-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[November 7]] until [[February 2]] - ""And Materials and Money in Crisis" (curated by Richard Birkett in dialogue with [[Sam Lewitt]]) at MOMUK (museum moderner kunst stiftung ludwig wien) [[Vienna, Austria]].<ref>https://www.mumok.at/sites/default/files/cms/01_pt_mumok_andmaterialsandmoneyandcrisis_e_0.pdf</ref> *[[December 3]] – February 23, 2014 - "[[Phyllida Barlow]]:HOARD" at the [[Norton Museum of Art]] in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norton.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=exhibitions.details&content_id=1096|title=Norton Museum of Art - Phyllida Barlow: HOARD|author=|date=|website=www.Norton.org|access-date=16 October 2017}}</ref>
==Works== <!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[File:Bay Bridge reflections at night.gif|thumb|right|A test of The Bay Lights on 24 January 2013]] -->
* [[March 5]] – ''[[The Bay Lights]]'', a 75th-anniversary [[Site-specific art|site-specific]] monumental [[light sculpture]] and [[art installation]] on the [[San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge]] designed by light artist [[Leo Villareal]], is inaugurated.<ref>{{cite news|last=Whiting|first=Sam|title=Bay Bridge to beam vivid light sculpture|url=http://www.sfgate.com/default/article/Bay-Bridge-to-beam-vivid-light-sculpture-3872898.php|accessdate=2013-01-23|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=2012-09-18}}</ref> * [[March 7]] – [[Peter Fischli & David Weiss]]'s ''[[Rock on Top of Another Rock]]'' is unveiled outside the [[Serpentine Galleries]] in London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.serpentinegalleries.org/exhibitions-events/fischli/weiss-rock-top-another-rock|title=A question of stability|publisher=Serpentine Galleries|year=2013|accessdate=2014-07-05}}</ref> * April – ''The Coronation Theatre, Westminster Abbey: A Portrait of [[Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II]]'', official painted portrait of The Queen to mark her [[Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II|Diamond Jubilee]], painted by Australian artist [[Ralph Heimans]] is shown at the [[National Portrait Gallery (Australia)|National Portrait Gallery]] in [[Canberra]], [[Australia]].<ref>{{cite web|url =http://www.portrait.gov.au/site/exhibition_subsite_glorious.php|title =Glorious: A Diamond Jubilee portrait of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II|publisher=National Portrait Gallery|accessdate=2013-06-14}}</ref> * Nuray Anahtar – ''[[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk (Anahtar)|Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]]'' (sculpture, Washington, D.C.) * [[Alex Chinneck]] - ''[[:File:From the knees of my nose to the belly of my toes.jpg|From the Knees of my Nose to the Belly of my Toes]]'' is installed in [[Margate]] and ''[[:File:Under the weather but over the moon.jpg|Under the Weather But Over the Moon]]'' in [[Blackfriars Road]], London, England. * William Cochran – ''[[Pillar of Fire (sculpture)|Pillar of Fire]]'' (sculpture, Washington, D.C.) * Devin Laurence Field – ''[[Barometer (sculpture)|Barometer]]'' (sculpture, Hillsboro, Oregon) * Blessing Hancock & Joe O'Connell – ''[[Heart Beacon]]'' (sculpture, Portland, Oregon) * Austin Weishel – ''[[Ashes to Answers]]'' (sculpture, Washington, D.C.)
==Awards== *The [[Venice Biennale]] (June 1-November 24): **Leone d'Oro ([[Golden Lion]]) for lifetime achievement: [[Maria Lassnig]] and [[Marisa Merz]] **Leone d'Oro for the Best Artist of the international exhibition: [[Tino Sehgal]] (United Kingdom/Germany) **Leone d'Oro for the Best Young Artist: Camille Henrot (France) **Leone d'Oro for Best Pavilion: [[Edson Chagas]] ([[Angola]]) *[[Praemium Imperiale]] laureate for sculpture – [[Antony Gormley]] (UK) *[[New Year Honours]] (UK) 2014 (announced 31 December 2013) – **[[Knight Bachelor]]: Antony Gormley *[[Carnegie Prize]] - [[Nicole Eisenman]]

revision.comment: /* Materials used to draw an Alpana */
revision.text:
'''Alpana''' or '''alpona''' ({{lang-bn|আল্পনা}}) refers to colourful motifs, sacred art or painting done with hands and paint which is mainly a paste of rice and flour on auspicious occasions in [[Bengal]].<ref name="hindu27122017">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/Reviving-a-vanishing-folk-art-form-in-Bengal/article16083431.ece|title=Reviving a vanishing folk art form in Bengal|date=27 December 2016|work=The Hindu|publisher=The Hindu Group|accessdate=7 October 2017}}</ref> The word Alpana is derived from the Sanskrit ''alimpana'', which means 'to plaster' or 'to coat with'. Traditionally, it was drawn by the women of the house before sunset. It is also a folk art in Bengal.
==Materials used to draw an Alpana== Traditionally in Bengal , alpana is strictly white since the liquid paste used for alpana is rice powder mixed in water. Nowadays there is somewhat change in materials. Some fabric colours are used along with some glue to give some long life of the alpana. Alpana is although generally white some green, red forms also drawn. Traditionally the green colouration done by tree leaves and red colour by sindur . It is also done with the cotton thread soaked in the liquid paste.
==Uses of Alpana== The art is known by different names in various parts of India and its use varies from region to region. The most common type of alpana all around India is [[Rangoli]], which uses colored sand to draw a design. The artwork is mainly done by women. They are conscious of the changing moods of the seasons and their creativity thus marks the changing cycle of the year.
Circular alpana is used as a holy pedestal during festivals such as the Bengal,Saraswati puja (also referred to as [[vasant panchami]]) in Bengal and the Festival of Lights ([[Diwali]]). Items drawn with the technique include the sun, swastika, a rice stem, an owl, a ladder, a plough, the footprints of the goddess [[Lakshmi]], a fish, [[betel]], a [[Padma (attribute)|lotus]], shankhalata (a snake)and some times just some abstract art to look beautiful . [[File:Alpana_on_saraswati_puja2.jpg|thumb|right|An Alpana]] [[File:Alpana_on_saraswati_puja1.jpg|thumb|right|Another Alpana]]
== See also == * [[Rangoli]] * [[Kolam]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

page.title: Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret

revision.comment: amd link
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret MET DP102925.jpg|thumb|The altarpiece]] The '''''Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret''''' is an autographed 1434 sculpture in [[Carrara marble]] by the Italian artist [[Andrea da Giona]], now in the collection of [[The Cloisters]] in [[New York City]]. It was commissioned by the Knights of Malta, a band of violent Christian sailors preoccupied with defending Spain from Muslim invasion.<ref name="w12">Wixom, 12</ref>
The carving is in the late [[International Gothic]] style, as evidenced by its folds of draperies, lush folidates, and the heavily idealised facial types of the main saints.<ref name="w12" />
[[Christ in Majesty]] is at the center, flanked by the Virgin Mary and the angel [[Gabriel]], with other angels playing musical instruments. The four [[Evangelism|Evangelists]] are placed at each corner. Inscriptions below the central panel read <small>"HOC OPUS FECIT MAGISTER AND[R]EAS DA GIONA MCCCCXXXIIII" (This work was made by Master Andrea from Giona 1434).</small><ref>"[http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/471909 Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret]". Retrieved 29 March 2016</ref> <gallery> File:Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret MET DP105433.jpg|Detail of the sculpture of Christ File:Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret MET DP105431.jpg|Detail of the sculpture of Christ File:Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret MET DP105432.jpg|Detail of the sculpture of Christ </gallery> <gallery> File:Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret MET DP105435.jpg|Detail of the sculpture of Saint John the Baptist File:Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret MET DP105430.jpg|Detail of the sculpture of a musical angel File:Altarpiece with Christ, Saint John the Baptist, and Saint Margaret MET DP105436.jpg|Detail of the sculpture of Saint Margaret </gallery> ==Notes== {{reflist|}}
==Sources==
* Wixom, William. "Medieval Sculpture at The Cloisters". ''The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin'', volume 46, no. 3, Winter, 1988–1989
[[Category:Sculptures of the Metropolitan Museum of Art]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]] [[Category:Sculptures of angels]] [[Category:Statues of Jesus]] [[Category:Statues of the Virgin Mary]] [[Category:Altarpieces]]

page.title: Australian Art: a Monthly Magazine & Journal

revision.comment: v1.43 - [[WP:WCW]] project (DEFAULTSORT missing for titles with special letters - Reference before punctuation - Spelling and typography)
revision.text:
[[File:Australian Art a montly magazine and journal 1888.jpg|thumb|Cover of Australian Art: a monthly magazine and journal. 1888]] {{Italic title}} '''''Australian Art: a Monthly Magazine & Journal''''',<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.obj-597211753|title=Australian art : a monthly magazine & journal.|website=nla.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article164358543|title=Art Publications.|date=1888-03-17|work=Sydney Mail and New South Wales Advertiser (NSW : 1871 - 1912)|access-date=2018-06-25|pages=571}}</ref> was a monthly [[magazine]] published in [[Sydney, New South Wales]], Australia. The publication's focus was to chronicle the progress of the fine arts in the Australasian colonies.<ref name=":3" /> Issues also included artist-proof engravings.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13672384|title=PUBLICATIONS RECEIVED.|date=1888-02-02|work=Sydney Morning Herald (NSW : 1842 - 1954)|access-date=2018-06-25|pages=6}}</ref><ref>https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/11671701</ref>
== History == The magazine was published by George Collingridge and Co., on the north shore of Sydney, New South Wales.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Citation | author1=Mitchell, Adrian | author2=Collingridge, George, 1847-1931, (artist.) | title=Plein airs and graces : the life and times of George Collingridge | publication-date=2012 | publisher=Wakefield Press | isbn=978-1-74305-095-8 }}</ref> It was the first Australian journal devoted to art.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.obj-299202620/findingaid|title=Papers of George Collingridge|website=nla.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref> Originally the magazine planned at least twelve months of issues,<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63621013|title=THE REWARD OF FAITHFUL SERYICE.|date=1888-03-15|work=Illustrated Sydney News (NSW : 1881 - 1894)|access-date=2018-06-25|pages=22}}</ref> however it appears that only three issues were published in January, February, and March 1888.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nla.gov.au/nla.obj-597211753|title=Australian art : a monthly magazine & journal.|website=nla.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref>
Some of the articles included in the three issues discussed Australian decorative art,<ref name=":2" /> essays on colour<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13683484|title=PUBLICATION RECEIVED.|date=1888-04-17|work=Sydney Morning Herald (NSW : 1842 - 1954)|access-date=2018-06-25|pages=4}}</ref> and the fine arts in Australia<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71095355|title=Our Bookshelf.|date=1888-03-17|work=Australian Town and Country Journal (Sydney, NSW : 1870 - 1907)|access-date=2018-06-25|pages=27}}</ref> and Exhibitions of the Art Society of New South Wales.<ref name=":3" /> The March 1888 issue of the magazine was criticised by ''[[The Sydney Mail and New South Wales Advertiser]]'' as having very little to do with Australian art and including too many illustrations from foreign subjects.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article164356834|title=New Publications.|date=1888-04-28|work=Sydney Mail and New South Wales Advertiser (NSW : 1871 - 1912)|access-date=2018-06-25|pages=900}}</ref>
== Digitisation == This magazine has been digitised on [[Trove]] by the [[National Library of Australia]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nla.gov.au/research-guides/first-world-war/newspapers-and-magazines|title=Newspapers and Magazines {{!}} National Library of Australia|website=www.nla.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref>
==See also== * [[George Collingridge]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Australian Art: a Monthly Magazine and Journal}} [[Category:Defunct magazines of Australia]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1888]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1888]] [[Category:Magazines published in Sydney]] [[Category:Australian monthly magazines]] [[Category:Art magazines]]

'''Avvisi''' ({{IPA-it|avˈviːzo|lang}}; plural: ''avvisi'') were hand-written [[newsletters]] used to convey political, military, and economic [[news]] quickly and efficiently throughout [[Europe]], and more specifically [[Italy]], during the [[early modern period|early modern era (1500-1700)]]. In the beginning avvisi were very similar to letters written from one dignitary to another, but diverged from such letters in the sixteenth century with more standardized practices. Avvisi can be divided into two categories: 'public' avvisi and 'secret' avvisi, though each copy was often written by the same person.Infelise, Mario. "Roman Avvisi: Information and Politics in the Seventeenth Century." Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002. 212,214,216-217. In [[Italian language|Italian]], the word '''[[wikt:avviso|avviso]]''' translates to ''notice'', ''warning'', ''advice'', or ''announcement''. ==Origin== The avvisi found their origins, and peaked, in the early modern Italian world - primarily Rome and Venice. The popularity and distribution of the avvisi was driven by each court's desire to know what the opposing and even the allied courts are up to. News networks spread all across Europe, but the avviso itself was generally created in either Rome or Venice, with the rest of Europe simply consuming.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} ==Importance== Avvisi influenced many aspects of the early modern world including public opinion, political battles, the nature of propaganda, careers, and historical records. '''Public Opinion'''
Avvisi helped to develop public opinion by informing, organizing, and providing a voice for the public. They allowed the general public to learn of the secret dealings of the nation's leaders, form a response, and then have that response actually be heard by their fellow citizens - essentially making them new players in the game of politics.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} '''Politics and War'''
Though officially renounced by many leaders at the time, avvisi were then used by those very same leaders to wage their political campaigns against one another. Destruction and [[censorship]] of avvisi was selective, demonstrating that the authorities recognized the importance of spreading news but would have preferred to spread only news that was of benefit to themselves.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} Competition quickly led to avvisi being used as propaganda devices both as a machine of war{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} and in attempts to turn the mob on their own country.DeVivo, Filippo. "Paolo Sarpi and the Uses of Information in Seventeenth-Century Venice." Media History, 11:1, 38. London: Routledge. 2005. Conflict as a result of avvisi being used as propaganda is certainly not out of the question, either with the public or between nations.Infelise, Mario. "Roman Avvisi: Information and Politics in the Seventeenth Century." Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002. 219. Further the avvisi provided the public with political power rarely seen before in the form of 'secret' information that could have allowed them to have influence upon the courts,{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} and government decisions. A minority of people, such as [[Paolo Sarpi]], believed that government institutions should rescind their censorship of avvisi and make full use of publication to combat enemy publication. An example of this includes several pamphlets written by Sarpi in defense of Venice's rights over the Adriatic.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} '''Finances and Wealth'''
Creation and distribution of avvisi required writers, those who can deliver the news, and those who can grant the information that makes the news and this provided many people with jobs, earning them money through standard means. In addition, invaluable secrets provided by the avvisi could be used in extortion or allowing individuals to influence prices at market. Those who used the avvisi in this way held the opinion that the information provided by avvisi could not be stopped and it was thus better to capitalize on it.DeVivo, Filippo. "Paolo Sarpi and the Uses of Information in Seventeenth-Century Venice." Media History, 11:1, 37,38. London: Routledge. 2005. '''History'''
Avvisi led to a realization of the importance of the after-effects of historical records, whether they be true or not. [[Paolo Sarpi]]'s work is an excellent example of this, as he states that he may cause more damage dead (through his writing) than he ever had alive.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} ==Types== ;Public avvisi Public avvisi were news letters that were available to anyone who wished to travel to a distribution center in a city. They were limited to generic, often harmless facts.Infelise, Mario. "Roman Avvisi: Information and Politics in the Seventeenth Century." Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002. 216,217,220. ;Secret avvisi Secret avvisi were news letters available to a restricted audience, much akin to duplicated personal letters. Their content could be considerably more harmful than the public counterpart, as it could include opinions of top officials and the discussions from secret meetings. This form of communication often had a very specific purpose.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} ==Distribution== Distribution of the avvisi began with the sources of information. Reporters (newsletter writers, menanti, reportisti, gazzettieri) had networks of contacts filtering information from chancelleries, Catholic churches, Protestant churches, foreign embassies,{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} and shops.DeVivo, Filippo. "Paolo Sarpi and the Uses of Information in Seventeenth-Century Venice." Media History, 11:1, 39,41. London: Routledge. 2005. Information was gathered and put together individually or at a [[Scrittoria]] (writer's workshop). The avvisi would then be distributed by regular news services and organized postal service networks. Whether newsletters were sent weekly, bi-weekly, or annually depended on the type of news and the writer.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}}Infelise, Mario. "Roman Avvisi: Information and Politics in the Seventeenth Century." Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002. 212,219,224. As the public avvisi were presented the news would quickly spread by word of mouth among the illiterate, no longer relying on the avvisi reporters. The range of information presented within avvisi was very broad, including countries such as France, Italy, and the Netherlands.DeVivo, Filippo. "Paolo Sarpi and the Uses of Information in Seventeenth-Century Venice." Media History, 11:1, 38,42. London: Routledge. 2005. ==Reporters== Writers of avvisi received very little recognition which, quite often, was exactly how they wanted it. Fear of censorship kept writers from signing work under their own name - for in the early modern era censorship could mean death. Mutual bonds of trust developed between certain reporters and clients once they found they could trust each other to provide reliable information without any trouble. The quality of avvisi may fall under question for numerous reasons; the recopying of documents, the translation of documents, and the insertion of opinions for example.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}}Infelise, Mario. "Roman Avvisi: Information and Politics in the Seventeenth Century." Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002. 216,219,220. ==Censorship== Censorship of avvisi began with [[Pope Pius V]]'s campaign, beginning in 1570CE. Writers caught distributing what the Catholic Church determined to be defamatory were punished severely - several examples of punishments include death, imprisonment, and torture (sometimes to death). The harsh punishments did not prevent writers from continuing in their task, though they were forced to use pseudonyms.DeVivo, Filippo. "Paolo Sarpi and the Uses of Information in Seventeenth-Century Venice." Media History, 11:1, 39. London: Routledge. 2005. The avvisi were blamed for causing disputes by church officials and writers. However, institutions that condemned avvisi found they could do nothing to quell the hand-written newsletters and began to use them to their own benefit, even with bans still in place.Infelise, Mario. "Roman Avvisi: Information and Politics in the Seventeenth Century." Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002. 214,215,217 Religious leaders were not alone in banning newsletters - more secular leaders also laid down limitations and prohibitions, including Venice's [[Council of Ten]] who held bans until at least 1567.DeVivo, Filippo. "Paolo Sarpi and the Uses of Information in Seventeenth-Century Venice." Media History, 11:1, 37. London: Routledge. 2005. A popular reporter, [[Paolo Sarpi]], was a minority in his time for holding the belief that the spread of information could not be stopped so censorship was a waste of resources. Sarpi believed that the only way to combat the enemy's newsletters is for the government to have their own avviso.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} ==Printed vs. Written== It was not until the middle of the seventeenth century that printed avvisi became more common, and even then Venice and Rome abstained from print. Due to restrictions from censorship on printed works, a sense of urgency, and a desire for personalization hand written avvisi would not be easily replaced by the printing press.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} Printed works were produced much more slowly and as a result the public would lose interest in the topic before it came to print.DeVivo, Filippo. "Paolo Sarpi and the Uses of Information in Seventeenth-Century Venice." Media History, 11:1, 48. London: Routledge. 2005. Further, printed avvisi were less robust in an effort to avoid censors and cut editing time.Infelise, Mario. "Roman Avvisi: Information and Politics in the Seventeenth Century." Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002. 227. ==See also== * [[List of the earliest newspapers]] * [[Gazetteer]] * [[Journalism]] * [[Journalist]] * [[Journal (disambiguation)]] * [[Newspaper]] * [[Printing press]] * [[Public sphere]] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== DeVivo, Filippo. "Paolo Sarpi and the Uses of Information in Seventeenth-Century Venice." Media History, 11:1, 37-51. London: Routledge. 2005. Infelise, Mario. "Roman Avvisi: Information and Politics in the Seventeenth Century." Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002. 212-228. ==External links== * Online Avvisi from Rome, Venice and other places of 1589 from [[Vatican Library]]: [http://digi.vatlib.it/view/MSS_Urb.lat.1057 Urb.Lat 1057] {{Periods of the History of Europe}} [[Category:Newspapers published in Italy]] [[Category:Early Modern period]] [[Category:Modern literature]]
