revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Karl Sovanka''' ('''Karol Šovánka''') (7 March 1893 in [[Uhrovec]], near [[Trenčín]], [[Slovakia]] – 1961 in [[Östringen]], Germany) was a painter and sculptor. He is world-known for his paintings of animals and hunting motifs.
He was a famous painter and sculptor from the town of [[Kezmarok|Kežmarok]]. He studied in [[Budapest]] (prof. Ľudovít Mátray), in [[Brussel]] (prof. van der Stappen), and in Paris. He was a member of the Slovak painters club in [[Bratislava]].
Sovanka was painting countrysides, animals and hunting motifs in nature, and he also made some sculptures and glasses. At an exhibition in [[Prague]] in 1931, he was exhibited with the oil paintings "Fox in the winter", "Dogs with boar", and others. Besides Slovakia and Prague, he also held exhibitions in [[Brno]] and Budapest.
Other famous paintings: [[Tatra Mountains|Tatra]]s countryside.
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{about||the big cat expert nicknamed Lion Man|Craig Busch|the New Zealand television documentary series called Lion Man|The Lion Man}} {{pp-move|reason=undiscussed move by IP|small=yes}}
[[File:Loewenmensch2.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|''Löwenmensch'', a lion-headed figurine found in Germany, dating to the [[Upper Paleolithic]] of about 35,000 to 40,000 years ago]] The '''Löwenmensch figurine''' or '''Lion-man of the Hohlenstein-Stadel''' is a prehistoric ivory [[sculpture]] that was discovered in the [[Hohlenstein-Stadel]], a German cave in 1939. The German name, '''Löwenmensch''' meaning "lion-human", is used most frequently because it was discovered and is exhibited in Germany.
The lion-headed figurine is the oldest-known [[zoomorphic]] (animal-shaped) sculpture in the world, and the oldest-known uncontested example of [[figurative art]]. It has been determined by [[carbon dating]] of the layer in which it was found to be between 35,000 and 40,000 years old, and therefore is associated with the archaeological [[Aurignacian]] culture of the Upper Paleolithic.<ref>[http://www.loewenmensch.de/figur_3.html 14C dating - The age of the lion man] Ulm Museum (in German)</ref> It was carved out of [[mammoth ivory]] using a [[flint]] stone knife. Seven parallel, transverse, carved gouges are on the left arm.
After several reconstructions that have incorporated newly found fragments, the figurine stands {{convert|31.1|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} tall, {{convert|5.6|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} wide, and {{convert|5.9|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick. It currently is displayed in the [[Ulm]] Museum, Germany.
==History== Systematic excavations at [[Hohlenstein-Stadel]] cave began in 1937 under the direction of prehistoric historian [[:de:Robert Wetzel (Anatom)|Robert Wetzel]].<ref>[http://www.loewenmensch.de/entdeckung_1939.html Discovery: 1939] Ulm Museum (in German)</ref> The discovery of a fragmented [[mammoth]]-[[ivory]] figurine was made on 25 August 1939 by geologist [[:de:Otto Völzing|Otto Völzing]].<ref name=spieg/> The start of World War II just one week later, meant that the [[fieldwork]] was left incomplete and analysis of the finds was not undertaken. The excavation trenches were backfilled with the same soil in which the ivory had been found.<ref name=lobell/>
For approximately thirty years, the fragments lay forgotten at the nearby [[:de:Ulmer Museum|Museum of Ulm]]. It was not until archaeologist [[Joachim Hahn]] started an inventory and assembly of more than 200 fragments that a figurine with animal and human features began to emerge.<ref name=lobell>{{cite journal|title=New Life for the Lion Man|author=Jarrett A. Lobell|date= March 2012|volume= 65|issue= 2|journal=Archaeology|url=http://archive.archaeology.org/1203/features/stadelhole_hohlenstein_paleolithic_lowenmensch.html}}</ref>
Wetzel continued to spend summers digging at the site until 1961,<ref>[http://www.loewenmensch.de/entdeckung_1956.html Discovery: 1956] Ulm Museum (in German)</ref> and further finds of ivory were made on the cave floor in the 1970s. In 1982, paleontologist [[Elisabeth Schmid]] combined the new fragments with Hahn's reconstruction, correcting some errors and adding pieces of the nose and mouth that emphasized the figurine's feline characteristics.<ref name=lobell/>{{efn|[http://donsmaps.com/images29/lionmenschhhh.jpg These images] of a preliminary reconstruction from 1980 shows how much has been achieved after years of painstaking reconstruction. (Adam, K., Kurz, R., 1980 ''Eiszeitkunst im süddeutschen Raum'')}}
In 1987, a comprehensive restoration began in the workshops of the [[Landesmuseum Württemberg]] by Ute Wolf in cooperation with Schmid. During the work, which took more than six months, it was realized that the figurine was only about two-thirds complete. The back is severely damaged and the legs are missing some ivory [[Lamella (materials)|lamellae]]. The ears, eye-holes, two-thirds of the mouth and nose, and the back of the head are preserved. To fill gaps in the head and body a reversible substance consisting of a mixture of beeswax, artificial wax, and chalk was used.<ref>[http://www.loewenmensch.de/entdeckung_1987.html Discovery: 1987] Ulm Museum (in German)</ref>
From 2008, further excavations were carried out in the cave. All layers were sifted systematically, which led to many minute fragments being discovered. The first new adjustments were simulated virtually so that fragments could be added without having to disassemble the original recreation.<ref>[http://www.loewenmensch.de/entdeckung_2011.html Discovery: 2011] Ulm Museum (in German)</ref>{{efn|[http://donsmaps.com/images24/lionladyreconst.jpg X-ray computed tomographs of "Löwenmenschen"] After restoration 1987/88 with new fragments from the 2010 excavation (red) and free fragments from the stock of the museum (green)}}
In 2012, a second restoration was begun in the workshops of the State Office for the Preservation of Historical Monuments in Esslingen under the leadership of [[Nicole Ebinger-Rist]]. The figurine was disassembled into its individual parts and newly discovered fragments were added along with the old ones, allowing further completion of areas of the head, back, and right side of the body, and artificial additions used during the first restoration were discarded.<ref name=ulmer2013/> The Löwenmensch figurine grew in height from 296 to 311 millimetres.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.swp.de/ulm/lokales/ulm_neu_ulm/loewenmensch-ist-gewachsen-11005726.html|author=Henning Petershagen|date=2 November 2013|title=Löwenmensch ist gewachsen|work=Südwest Presse}}</ref> Work was completed in late 2013.<ref name=ulmer2013>[http://www.loewenmensch.de/entdeckung_2013.html Discovery: 2011] Ulm Museum (in German)</ref>
==Interpretation== [[File:Loewenmensch1.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|The Löwenmensch figurine after restoration in 2013]] Assignment of gender became an objective of certain researchers. Initially, the figurine was classified as male by Hahn who suggested a plate on the abdomen could be a flaccid penis. Schmid later classified this feature as a pubic triangle,<ref name=spieg>{{cite news|title=Puzzle im Schutt|work=Der Spiegel|author=Matthias Schulz|date=5 December 2011|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-82612721.html}}</ref> however, and from examination of new parts of the sculpture, determined that the figurine was that of a woman with the head of a "''{{lang|de|Höhlenlöwin}}''" (female [[Panthera leo spelaea|European cave lion]]).<ref name="sc">{{Cite web |first=Jochen |last=Duckeck |date=2008-12-10 |title=Archäologie: Der Löwenmensch |url=http://www.showcaves.com/german/explain/Archaeology/Loewenfrau.html |language=German |quote=Joachim Hahn hatte die Figur als männlich betrachtet. Elisabeth Schmid kam zu dem Schluß, dass es sich um die Figur einer Frau mit dem Kopf einer Höhlenlöwin handele. |accessdate=2009-05-17 |postscript=. |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521210909/http://www.showcaves.com/german/explain/Archaeology/Loewenfrau.html |archive-date=2009-05-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }} and {{Cite web |first=Jochen |last=Duckeck |date=2008-12-10 |title=Archaeology: Lionheaded Figurine |url=http://www.showcaves.com/english/explain/Archaeology/Loewenfrau.html |accessdate=2009-05-17 |postscript=. }}</ref> Male European cave lions often lacked distinctive manes, so the absence of a mane could not determine categorically that the figurine was that of a lioness, and a debate about its gender ensued among some involved in the research and the popular press. Kurt Wehrberger of the Ulm Museum stated that the statue had become an "icon of the feminist movement".<ref name=spieg/>
After the 2012–13 restoration it was realized that the triangular platelet in the genital area was processed all around separating it from the figurine. A fracture point suggests that originally it may have been square in shape. Although an objective determination of the gender of the Löwenmensch figurine is impossible, debate continues, with the most common interpretation of the fragment being a stylized male sex organ.<ref>[http://www.loewenmensch.de/bedeutung4.html Importance: Sex?] Ulm Museum (in German)</ref>
The Löwenmensch figurine lay in a chamber almost 30 metres from the entrance of the Stadel cave and was accompanied by many other remarkable objects. Bone tools and worked antlers were found, along with jewellery consisting of pendants, beads, and perforated animal teeth. The chamber was probably a special place, possibly used as a storehouse or hiding-place, or maybe as an area for cultic rituals.<ref>[http://www.loewenmensch.de/bedeutung2.html Importance: Depot - hiding place - cult place?] Ulm Museum (in German)</ref>
A similar but smaller lion-headed human sculpture was found along with other animal figurines and several flutes in the nearby [[Vogelherd Cave]]. This leads to the possibility that the Löwenmensch figurines were important in the [[mythology]] of humans of the early [[Upper Paleolithic]]. Archaeologist [[Nicholas Conard]] has suggested that the second lion-figurine "lends support to the hypothesis that Aurignacian people may have practised [[shamanism]] ... and that it should be considered strong evidence for fully symbolic communication and cultural modernity".<ref name="CoolidgeWynn2011">{{cite book|author1=Frederick L. Coolidge|author2=Thomas Wynn|title=The Rise of Homo sapiens: The Evolution of Modern Thinking|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pZHtlD7Ife8C&pg=PT174|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-5653-3|page=174}}</ref>
The figurine shares certain similarities with later French cave paintings, which also show hybrid creatures with human-like lower bodies and animal heads such as the "[[The Sorcerer (cave art)|Sorcerer]]" from the [[Trois Frères]] in the Pyrennes or the "[[Bison-man (cave art)|Bison-man]]" from the [[Grotte de Gabillou]] in the Dordogne.<ref>[http://www.loewenmensch.de/bedeutung3.html Importance: Animal and human being] Ulm Museum (in German)</ref>
==Manufacture== The carving of the figurine from hard mammoth tusk would have been a complex and time-consuming task.{{efn|[http://donsmaps.com/images29/lioncarvinginsitu.jpg This image] shows the positioning of the figurine within the tusk. Schmid found that the groin area coincided with the apex of the tusk's [[Pulp (tooth)|pulp cavity]]. "The long axis of the figure follows the nerve canal with the head at the narrowing end. This expert positioning suggests that the make deliberately selected a portion of the tusk suitable for a preconceived work." (Cook, 2013)}} A similarly-sized tusk found in the same cave has marks that "indicate that the skin and thin bone around the tooth cavity of the upper jaw were cut through to the surface of the tooth, which was then exposed for detachment with a hammer. The tip was harder and had to be removed by wedging and splitting."<ref name=cook/>
Wulf Hein and Kurt Wehrberger conducted an [[Experimental archaeology|experimental]] replication with the kinds of stone tool available at the time. Removing the base of the tusk took ten hours. The body was carved with a steep-fronted scraper; the [[Burin (lithic flake)|burin]]s requiring regular resharpening. Several different tools were needed to separate the torso from the insides of the arms while shaping the head and shoulders, which involved difficult cutting across the grain of the ivory, often required two hands on the tool. The basic shaping took around 200 hours, and in total the recreation took more than 370 hours.{{efn|The Ulm Museum site says 360 hours, Cook (2013) says 320, whereas the video made by the team says 370+}} Jill Cook, Curator of Paleolithic collections at the British Museum, suggests that "unless the sculpture was created slowly at odd moments over several months, someone as skilled as an artist may have been excused from other subsistence tasks to work specially on this piece."<ref name=cook>{{cite book|author= Cook, J.|title= Ice Age art: arrival of the modern mind|publisher= The British Museum|date= 18 February 2013|isbn=978-0714123332}}</ref>
In his October 2017 [[BBC Radio 4]] series ''[[Living with the Gods]]'', [[Neil MacGregor]] asked Cook "[…] so why would a community living on the edge of subsistence, whose primary concerns were finding food, keeping that fire going, protecting children from predators, allow someone to spend so much time away from those tasks?", to which she replied that it was about "[…] a relationship to things unseen, to the vital forces of nature, that you need to perhaps propitiate, perhaps connect to, in order to ensure your successful life".<ref name="BBC Living With The Gods">{{cite episode| title= The Beginnings of Belief| episodelink= | series= Living With The Gods | serieslink= | credits= Presenter: [[Neil MacGregor]]; Producer: Paul Kobrak| network= BBC| station= [[BBC Radio 4]]| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b099xhmj| minutes= 06:08| airdate= 23 October 2017| accessdate= 23 October 2017 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Hohle Fels]] * [[List of Stone Age art]] * [[Prehistoric art]] * [[Venus of Hohle Fels]]
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Ulmer Museum (Ed.): ''The return of the Lion Man. History - Myth - Magic''. Ostfildern 2013. {{ISBN|978-3-7995-0544-4}} (museum's edition); {{ISBN|978-3-7995-0543-7}} (publisher's edition)
==External links== {{Commons category|Löwenmensch|Lion-man}} *[http://www.loewenmensch.de/lion_man.html Official website of the museum] (in German) *[http://www.donsmaps.com/lionlady.html Don's maps site with a collection of material on the figurine] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hgbvT9_pjzo Lion Man 2.0 - The Experiment] Video showing the manufacture of a replica with authentic tools (in German with English subtitles) *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b099xhmj BBC Radio 4 episode about the sculpture] (2017)

page.title: List of Olympic medalists in art competitions

revision.comment: Bot: [[User:KolbertBot|HTTP→HTTPS]] (v485)
revision.text:
[[File:Baron Pierre de Coubertin.jpg|thumb|alt=Photograph of Pierre de Coubertin|Under the pseudonyms Georges Hohrod and Martin Eschbach, [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]] founder [[Pierre de Coubertin]] won a gold medal in the literature category at the [[Art competitions at the 1912 Summer Olympics|1912 Summer Olympics]].]] There were '''146 medalists''' in [[Art competitions at the Summer Olympics|the art competitions]] that were part of the [[Olympic Games]] from [[1912 Summer Olympics|1912]] until [[1948 Summer Olympics|1948]]. These art competitions were considered an integral part of the movement by [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) founder [[Pierre de Coubertin]] and necessary to recapture the complete essence of the [[Ancient Olympic Games]]. Their absence before the [[1912 Summer Olympics]], according to journalism professor Richard Stanton, stems from Coubertin "not wanting to fragment the focus of his new and fragile movement".{{cite book|last = Stanton|first = Richard|title = The Forgotten Olympic Art Competitions|publisher = [[Trafford Publishing]]|edition = 1st|date = 2000|location = [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]]|page = 3|isbn = 1552126064}} Art competitions were originally planned for inclusion in the [[1908 Summer Olympics]] but were delayed after that edition's change in venue from Rome to London following the 1906 eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius]].Stanton, p. 18. By the [[1924 Summer Olympics]] they had grown to be considered internationally relevant and potentially "a milestone in advancing public awareness of art as a whole".Stanton, p. 69. During their first three appearances, the art competitions were grouped into five broad categories: architecture, literature, music, painting, and sculpture. The Dutch Organizing Committee for the [[1928 Summer Olympics]] split these into subcategories in the hopes of increasing participation.Stanton, p. 95. Although it was a successful strategy, the [[1932 Summer Olympics]] eliminated several of these subcategories, which led to fewer entries in the broader categories.Stanton, p. 146. For the [[1936 Summer Olympics]], the German government proposed the addition of a film contest to the program, which was rejected.Stanton, p. 158. Following a final appearance at the [[1948 Summer Olympics]], art competitions were removed from the Olympic program. Planners of the [[1952 Summer Olympics]] opposed their inclusion on logistical grounds, claiming that the lack of an international association for the event meant that the entire onus of facilitation was placed on the local organizing committee.Stanton, p. 210. Concerns were also raised about the professionalism of the event, since only amateurs were allowed to participate in the sporting tournaments,Stanton, p. 211. and the growing commercialization of the competitions, as artists had been permitted to sell their submissions during the course of the Games since 1928. In 1952 an art festival and exhibition was held concurrent with the Games, a tradition that has been maintained in all subsequent Summer [[Olympic games|Olympics]].Stanton, p. 213. The IOC does not track medalists in Olympic art competitions in its database and thus the prize winners are only officially recorded in the original Olympic reports. Judges were not required to distribute first, second, and third place awards for every category, and thus certain events lack medalists in these placements. Since participants were allowed multiple submissions, it was also possible for artists to win more than one in a single event, as [[Alex Diggelmann]] of Switzerland did in the graphic arts category of the 1948 edition.{{cite journal|title = The Official Report of the Organising Committee for the XIV Olympiad London 1948|page = 536|publisher = The Organising Committee for the XIV Olympiad|location = [[London]]|date = 1951|url = http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1948/OR1948part2.pdf|format = PDF|accessdate = 2012-03-06}} Diggelmann is tied with Denmark's [[Josef Petersen]], who won second prize three times in literature, for the amount of medals captured in the art competitions. Luxembourg's [[Jean Jacoby]] is the only individual to win two gold medals, doing so in painting in 1924 and 1928. Of the 146 medalists, 11 were women and only Finnish author [[Aale Tynni]] was awarded gold. Germany was the most successful nation, with eight gold, seven silver, and nine bronze medals,{{cite web|last = Gjerde|first = Arild|author2 = Jeroen Heijmans|author3 = Bill Mallon|author4 = Hilary Evans|title = Art Competitions|work = Olympics|publisher = Sports Reference.com|year = 2011|url = https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/sports/ART/|accessdate = 2012-03-07|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/66VSjSXMP?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/sports/ART/|archivedate = 2012-03-28|deadurl = no|df = }} although one was won by Coubertin himself, a Frenchman. He submitted his poem ''Ode to Sport'' under the pseudonyms Georges Hohrod and Martin Eschbach, as if it were a joint-entry, and won first prize in the 1912 literature category. The original report credits this medal to Germany.{{cite web|last = Gjerde|first = Arild|author2 = Jeroen Heijmans|author3 = Bill Mallon|author4 = Hilary Evans|title = Pierre, Baron de Coubertin Biography and Olympic Results|work = Olympics|publisher = Sports Reference.com|year = 2011|url = https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/de/pierre-baron-de-coubertin-1.html|accessdate = 2012-03-07|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/66VT2aWgB?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/de/pierre-baron-de-coubertin-1.html|archivedate = 2012-03-28|deadurl = no|df = }} Two individuals, [[Walter W. Winans]]{{cite web|last = Gjerde|first = Arild|author2 = Jeroen Heijmans|author3 = Bill Mallon|author4 = Hilary Evans|title = Walter Winans Biography and Olympic Results|work = Olympics|publisher = Sports Reference.com|year = 2011|url = https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/wi/walter-winans-1.html|accessdate = 2012-03-08|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/66VT5TLLP?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/wi/walter-winans-1.html|archivedate = 2012-03-28|deadurl = no|df = }} and [[Alfréd Hajós]], won medals in both athletic and art competitions.{{cite web|last = Gjerde|first = Arild|author2 = Jeroen Heijmans|author3 = Bill Mallon|author4 = Hilary Evans|title = Alfréd Hajós Biography and Olympic Results|work = Olympics|publisher = Sports Reference.com|year = 2011|url = https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ha/alfred-hajos-1.html|accessdate = 2012-03-08|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/66VTAaxrD?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ha/alfred-hajos-1.html|archivedate = 2012-03-28|deadurl = no|df = }} == Architecture == === Mixed architecture === [[File:Hajos.jpg|thumb|175px|alt=Photograph of Alfréd Hajós|[[Alfréd Hajós]] was one of two individuals to win medals in sport and art competitions.]] {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+Olympic medalists in mixed architecture ! scope="col" style="width:105px;" |Games ! scope="col" style="background-color:gold; width:180px;" |Gold ! scope="col" style="background-color:silver; width:180px;" |Silver ! scope="col" style="background-color:#cc9966; width:180px;" |Bronze |- ! scope="row" |[[1912 Summer Olympics|1912 Stockholm]] |{{flagIOCathlete|{{Hs|Monod}}[[Eugène-Edouard Monod]] & [[Alphonse Laverrière]]|SUI|1912 Summer}}

page.title: List of feminist avant-garde artists of the 1970s

revision.comment: /* Footnotes */
revision.text:
{{short description|Wikimedia list article}} This is a '''list of games at [[Funspot Family Fun Center]]''', located in the village of [[Weirs Beach, New Hampshire|Weirs Beach]] in [[Laconia, New Hampshire]], [[United States]]. Funspot is ranked by [[Guinness World Records]] as the world's largest arcade.<ref>[http://gamers.guinnessworldrecords.com/news/270508_largest_arcade.aspx Come meet a Guinness World Records Judge and compete for a chance to be in the Guinness World Records Gamer's Edition 2009!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016100404/http://gamers.guinnessworldrecords.com/news/270508_largest_arcade.aspx |date=2009-10-16 }} Guinness World Records: Gamer's Edition. May 27, 2008 Accessed August 26, 2009</ref><ref name=Roadside>[http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/22471 American Classic Arcade Museum] Roadside America. Accessed August 28, 2009</ref> The majority of games at Funspot are part of the American Classic Arcade Museum's collection, a non-profit organization located on Funspot's second floor,<ref name=Roadside /> whose goal is to "promote and preserve the history of coin-operated arcade games."<ref>[http://www.classicarcademuseum.org/mission2.htm The American Classic Arcade Museum, Inc. Mission Statement] American Classic Arcade Museum.Accessed August 26, 2009</ref>
==Games==
<!-------Please do not add games to any of these lists unless you can reference that they are at Funspot--------->
The following tables list games located at Funspot. The lists are divided into the American Classic Arcade Museum games and games elsewhere in the center.
===American Classic Arcade Museum===

page.title: List of video game collector and limited editions

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|All typo fixes]] on, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: Assassin’s → Assassin's (48)
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=January 2017}} '''Computer and video game collector and limited editions''' (commonly referred to as CE and LE's) are [[video games]] packaged with [[Special edition|bonus materials and enhancements]] not available in the standard release. Such bonuses can range from special packaging to printed artwork to extra discs containing additional content. These versions are typically of a predetermined limited release and act as promotional tools for the publisher, and items of value for collectors."For the Fans: ''GI'' Looks into Limited Editions," ''Game Informer'' 179 (March 2008): 18-19. Not all titles released as a "Special/Collector's/Etc. Edition" are necessarily in any substantial way superior to the standard edition. True Collector's and Limited Editions are those released with extra materials or content, that were limited in every case. For example, most [[Game of the Year]], Gold, or Platinum editions are [[Reissue|re-releases]] and rarely contain anything of extra value nor are of particular limited release, and thus are not generally considered Collector's or Limited Editions. {{GamePlatformKey|tot=21|NDS|3DS|DC|GB|GBC|GBA|Mac|Win|PS2|PS3|PS4|PSP|PSVita|N64|GCN|Wii|WiiU|NS|Xbox|X360|XBO}} ==#== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Video games !Platforms !Details |- | ''' ''[[The 3rd Birthday]]'' Twisted Edition | [[PlayStation Portable|PSP]] |Comes in a special card board case with new art work, CTI Confidential Hard back book, 2 Deluxe Aya Brea art prints, Exclusive Aya Brea Lightning costume for use in [[Dissidia 012 Final Fantasy]]. |} ==A== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Video games !Platform(s) !Details !Release Year |- | ''' ''[[Adventure Time: Explore the Dungeon Because I Don't Know!]]'' Collector's Edition | [[Nintendo 3DS|3DS]] |Includes the game, making-of DVD, Dungeon guide and exclusive oversized steel case. | 2013 |- | ''' ''[[Age of Empires III]]'' Collector's Edition | [[Microsoft Windows|Win]] | Oversized sliding case, hardbound 210-page "The Art of Empires" book, a "Making of Age of Empires III" DVD with behind-the-scenes video and commentary, the official soundtrack, a 43-in. × 27-in. full-color poster of concept art, an exclusive Player's Guide, and a Collector's Edition Game Manual.{{cite web|url=http://pc.ign.com/objects/766/766435.html |title=IGN: Age of Empires III (Collector's Edition) |publisher=Pc.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}}http://collectorsedition.org/game-db/age-of-empires-iii-collectors-edition-pc-dvd-rom | 2005 |- | ''' ''[[Alan Wake]]'' Limited Collector's Edition | [[Xbox 360|X360]] | Contained in Hardback book packaging. Contains bonus DVD with the option of installing audio commentaty to Alan Wake game, partial game soundtrack (including both licensed songs as well as the Alan Wake score) and a collectors book 'The Alan Wake Files'. The book is written by a character within the Alan Wake universe rather than a concept art book.http://collectorsedition.org/game-db/alan-wake-limited-collectors-edition-xbox-360-ntsc-j | 2010 |- | ''' ''[[Aliens VS Predator]]'' Hunter Edition | [[PlayStation 3|PS3]]
X360 | Tin case, a replica of a facehugger, a Wayland Yutani Corp patch, 4 extra levels and a holographic piece of card. | 2010 |- | ''' ''[[Anno 1404]]'' Collector's Edition | Win | Packaged in a large wooden box, includes the game, a 72-page art book, a panoramic poster, an old fashioned compass, a bag containing 6 almond seeds and an exclusive bonus DVD.{{cite web|last=Entertainment |first=Blizzard |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B002DWAZQ2 |title=Anno 1404 (Collector's Edition) |publisher=Amazon |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} | 2009 |- | ''' ''[[Assassin's Creed (video game)|Assassin's Creed]]'' Limited Edition | PS3
X360 | Held in a special tin box, the Limited Edition features a figurine of lead hero Altair, a set of Penny Arcade comics, a Mini-strategy guide and bonus disc with Assassin-themed short films and additional Assassin's Creed videos.{{cite web | url=http://xbox360.ign.com/objects/908/908108.html | title=Assassin's Creed (Limited Edition) | publisher=IGN | accessdate=2007-11-18}} | 2007 |- | ''' ''[[Assassin's Creed II]]'' Master Assassin Edition | PS3
X360 | NA Exclusive - Includes Ezio Auditore da Firenze figurine, Artbook: The Art of Assassin's Creed, Premium collectible metal case, 2 in-game bonus missions: Palazzo Medici and Santa Maria dei Frari and lastly additional content DVD with the Behind the Scenes of Assassin's Creed and Assassin's Creed II soundtrack. | 2009 |- | ''' ''Assassin's Creed II'' White Edition | PS3
X360 | PAL only. Comes boxed with the game, Exclusive bonus quest & collectable Ezio Auditore Da Firenze figurine. | 2009 |- | ''' ''Assassin's Creed II'' Black Edition | PS3
X360 | PAL only - Includes Collectible black packaging with unique authentic holographic signature, "Master Assassin" variant of Ezio Figure, 3 in game bonus quests, "Conspiracy Book" leather bound book containing information and production images from the game & Game Soundtrack CD. | 2009 |- | ''' ''[[Assassin's Creed III]]'' Limited Edition | Win
PS3
X360 |NA Exclusive - Includes George Washington's notebook, A statue of Ratonhnhaké:ton with tomahawk and Hidden Blade, Assassin's Creed-inspired colonial flag and a metal belt buckle. | 2009 |- | ''' ''Assassin's Creed III'' Freedom Edition | Win
PS3
X360 | PAL Exclusive - Includes a steel book case, with cover art drawn by award-winning comic artist Alex Ross, A collector's box, A 24 centimeter high quality figurine of Connor, An exclusive lithograph, George Washington's notebook, An additional Animi Avatar, the Sharpshooter and two exclusive single player missions, Lost Mayan Ruins and Ghost of War. | 2012 |- | ''' ''Assassin's Creed III'' Join or Die Edition | Win
PS3
X360 | PAL Exclusive - Includes A collector's box, Ratonhnhaké:ton's medallion, George Washington's notebook, An exclusive single player mission, Ghost of War, An additional Animi Avatar "the Sharpshooter." | 2012 |- | ''' ''[[Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag]]'' Black Chest Editionhttp://collectorsedition.org/game-db/assassins-creed-iv-black-flag-black-chest-edition-pc-dvd-rom | [[Nintendo Wii U|WiiU]]

The Limited Edition of Sonic Adventure was originally distributed to approximately 400 Funcoland locations as a disc-only release to be used in Dreamcast kiosks promoting the upcoming release of the console. These discs included a trimmed down version of the game based on the Japanese release and had saving and network connectivity disabled along with other minor differences; they were known to be buggy. Later, a variant of the release was distributed to Hollywood Video as part of a pre-release promotion in which the game could be rented along with a console before it's official launch. This variant of the game allowed saving and included a case and manual. The disc, game manual cover, and spine of the case all state “Limited Edition” and the artwork differs slightly from the standard edition release. Due to its exclusive distribution through a rental chain many of the original game cases were lost or destroyed and replaced in whole or in part with cases or manuals from the standard edition release, also many discs were tagged with a “Hollywood Video” security sticker. | 1999 |- | ''' ''[[Sonic Adventure 2]]'' 10th Birthday Edition | DC |Pre-order bonus with Sonic Adventure 2. Contains special soundtrack CD, golden Sonic coin & special booklet, packaged in a blue foldout box.
