Chronicle 1'' – additional scene, official soundtrack, dynamic XMB menu theme. *''[[Hyperdimension Neptunia]]'' Premium Edition — Alternative game box cover and Full Color Hard Cover Artwork included only for PS3. *''[[Infamous (video game)|Infamous]]'' Collector's edition — Comes packaged in slip case box and includes the game, downloadable code for "Gigawatt Blades" power & exclusive comic/artbook featuring locations and characters from the game. *''[[Killzone 2]]'' Limited Collector's Edition Tin Box Case, United Kingdom Exclusive. *''[[Killzone 3]]'' Limited Collector's Edition Steelbook with Bonuses, Europe Exclusive. *''[[Kingdom Hearts HD 1.5 Remix]]'' - pre-orders included a book of the game's concept artwork *''[[Infamous 2]]'' Hero Edition — comes with Cole's Sling pack replica, copy of inFamous 2, Cole's statuette and super voucher that unlocks "Lightning Hook" and "Electrecution Grenade" powers, Golden Amp skin, Kessler skin and original Cole skin. *''[[The Last of Us]]'' Joel and Ellie Editions both contains canvas wrap, mini artbook, mini comic, screen print effect poster, Joel or Ellie [[DualShock 3]] wireless controller skin, [[LittleBigPlanet]] Joel or Ellie [[Sackboy]] skin, Sight & Sounds pack (a PS3 dynamic theme, a digital download of the game soundtrack, two exclusive PSN avatars) and Survival pack (special customisable items for your multiplayer character, start with a pool of in-game currency to buy boosters, customisable parts and other items to bolster your multiplayer characters, bonus experience points to give you a head start to your rivals, a powerful melee attack booster to pack a heavier punch in hand-to-hand combat, two bonus skins for Joel and Ellie – available once you've completed the single player game). Survival Edition contains full size artbook, steelbook edition of the game, ''The Last of Us – American Dreams #1'' comic, Sights & Sounds DLC pack, [[Naughty Dog]] sticker sheet. Post-pandemic Edition includes 12 inch premium statue, steelbook edition of the game, ''The Last of Us – American Dreams #1'' comic, Survival DLC pack, Sights & Sounds DLC pack, Naughty Dog sticker sheet. Special Limited Edition is exclusive for [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] Italy and contains a metal water bottle, 30-day [[PlayStation Network#PlayStation Plus|PlayStation Plus]] subscription, a DualShock sticker skin featuring artwork of Joel and Ellie, Sight & Sounds pack. *''[[LittleBigPlanet 2]]'' Collecter's Edition — The Collector's Edition of LittleBig Planet 2 includes the Sackboy Plush Toy, The LittleBig Planet Book ends, codes for exclusive costumes, (Disney Pixars Toy Story 3 Alien, Tron's Clu, The Muppets Gonzo the Great, Vulture, Cobra, Crocodile, Mandrill, Jak and Daxter, and Rachet and Clack) codes for 6 exclusive sackboy related avtars. *''[[Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots]]'' Limited Edition{{cite web|url=http://ps3.ign.com/objects/142/14242494.html |title=IGN: Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots (Limited Edition) |publisher=Ps3.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — comes packaged in a collectible metal case and includes a supplemental Blu-ray video and soundtrack CD. UK Play.com Exclusive version of this also included a 6" Old Snake figurine. *''[[Ninja Gaiden Sigma]]'' Collector's Edition{{cite web|url=http://ps3.ign.com/objects/909/909552.html |title=IGN: Ninja Gaiden Sigma (Collector's Edition) |publisher=Ps3.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — bonus DVD featuring behind-the-scenes footage of [[Team Ninja]] as well as special unlock codes for different mission modes *''[[Ninja Gaiden Sigma 2]]'' Collector's Edition — [[Gamestop]] Exclusive. Contains: 30-page prologue comic, mini-strategy guide, and an on disc Art Gallery and commentary from [[Team Ninja]] *''[[Resistance 2]]'' Collector's Edition — Includes an exclusive 5.5-inch Chimera Hybrid action figure, art book and DVD. *''[[Spider-Man 3 (video game)|Spider-Man 3]]'' Collector's Edition{{cite web|url=http://ps3.ign.com/objects/887/887284.html |title=IGN: Spider-Man 3 (Collector's Edition) |publisher=Ps3.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — players can play as "[[Harry Osborn#Spider-Man 3|New Goblin]]", exclusive webisodes from the ''[[Spider-Man 3]]'' movie, an interview with producer [[Avi Arad]], behind the scenes talks with the film's cast and more. *''[[Tales of Graces|Tales of Graces f]] - Europe exclusively received a making-of DVD, soundtrack and artbook *''[[Tales of Xillia]]'' Collector's Edition includes character figure, artbook and music cd. Limited Edition includes character profile booklet and music cd. *''[[Tekken 6]]'' Limited Edition/Collector's Edition — Tekken 6 game for Xbox 360 or PS3 which comes with a few special Tekken items which are the white Xbox 360 Tekken 6 hoody/sweatshirt or the black PS3 Tekken 6 hoody/sweatshirt and the Tekken 6 Art Book and also a big size Tekken 6 poster of Lars Alexandersson. Limited Edition is the European name of this version and Collector's Edition is the American/Asian name for this *''[[Tekken 6]]'' Wireless Arcade Stick Bundle/Limited Edition — Tekken 6 game for Xbox 360 or PS3 which comes with the Tekken 6 Art Book and an exclusively made HORI Tekken 6 arcade stick with an 8-button layout and Tekken art upper deck. Limited Edition is the American/Asian name for this version. *''[[Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception]]'' Explorer Edition - Nathan Drake Statue, Replica Belt Buckle, Replica ring with necklace scrap, JAP only Limited Uncharted 3 DualShock 3 controller, US only Steelbook Case, EU/AUS only Special Edition cover, US only Travelling Chest, EU/AUS only Wooden Traveller's Box, and DLC codes for Regeneration Booster, Cash Multiplier, London Drake skin, Pirate AK47, Uppercut taunt, Callout mod for AK47, Clip size mod for Para-9, Clip size mod for G-MAL, Carpet bomb kickback, Creepy Crawler kickback. *''[[WWE SmackDown vs. Raw 2009]]'' Collector's Edition — exclusive 'steel cage' packaging and a Blu-ray Disc featuring over 2 hours of wrestling footage and 'The Making of Smackdown vs Raw 2009' Documentary. ==[[Wii]]== *''[[Animal Crossing: Let's Go To The City]] Limited Edition — Comes with Wii Speak. *''[[The Conduit]] Limited Edition — features a 24-page concept art booklet, a code for a multiplayer skin "Suit", a code for a custom ASE in single player, and a code to play as a drone in the campaign. *''[[Cursed Mountain]] Limited Edition (NA Only) - Includes Bonus Disc with 15 tracks of in-game music and a 5-part "making of" DVD. Interior Art in Steelbook case. *''[[Epic Mickey]] Collector's Edition — 5" exclusive Epic Mickey figurine, Making of DVD, Console & Remote skins/faceplate. *''[[GoldenEye 007 (2010 video game)|GoldenEye 007]] Classic Edition — Includes game, Golden Classic Controller Pro & Code to unlock conflict mode in multiplayer with 8 classic Bond characters. *''[[The House Of The Dead: Overkill]] Collector's Edition — Game comes in an exclusive slipcase & includes "Prelude To An Overkill" graphic novel. *''[[Kirby's Dream Collection]] An anthology disc celebrating the series' 20th anniversary. The disc includes six Kirby titles: Kirby's Dream Land, Kirby's Adventure, Kirby's Dream Land 2, Kirby Super Star, Kirby's Dream Land 3 and Kirby 64: The Crystal Shards, new challenge stages based on those found in Kirby's Return to Dream Land, a museum section and three episodes from Kirby: Right Back at Ya! In addition to the disc, the package includes a booklet that highlights Kirby's history, as well as a soundtrack containing music from multiple series entries. *''[[The Last Story]] Limited Edition initial print includes 44-page artbook and special packaging. PAL region received a steelbook case, soundtrack and mini artbook. *''[[The Legend of Zelda: Link's Crossbow Training]] - includes Wii Zapper *''[[The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword]] Limited edition includes{{cite web|author=Nintendo |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Legend-Zelda-Skyward-Limited-Remote/dp/B005KJLAOQ/ref=sr_1_2?s=videogames&ie=UTF8&qid=1330536067&sr=1-2 |title=The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword - Limited Edition Gold Wii Remote Bundle: Amazon.co.uk: PC & Video Games |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} - A Legend of Zelda sound track of Zelda throughout all the games and golden Wii Remote Plus (with motion plus) *''[[Metroid Prime: Trilogy]] Collector's Edition — Includes the game, exclusive Steelbook case with slipcover, and booklet containing concept art and history of the game trilogy. *''[[Monster Hunter Tri]] Limited Ultimate Hunter Pack{{cite web|url=http://www.game.co.uk/Games/Wii/Action-Adventure/Monster-Hunter-Tri-Limited-Edition-Ultimate-Hunter-Pack/~r346855/?s=monster+hunter+tri |title=Consoles & Games for Xbox 360, PS3, Wii, 3DS & PSP with FREE UK delivery! |publisher=GAME |date=2012-02-29 |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — UK. special box shaped like a chest from the game and includes a copy of the game, Wii speak accessory & a black Classic Controller Pro. *''[[Pandora's Tower]] Limited Edition — Comes with Artbook. *''[[Super Mario All-Stars]] 25th Anniversary Edition — Limited Edition Re-release of the SNES compilation "Super Mario All-Stars" on Wii, A special 32 page book containing the history of Mario & a Soundtrack CD containing a piece of music from the main Mario titles up until Super Mario Galaxy 2, All packaged in a Red Mario box. *''[[Super Smash Bros Brawl]] Limited Edition - With bonus sleeve. *''[[Xenoblade Chronicles]] Limited Edition - With Red Classic Controller Pro. *''[[Zumba Fitness 1 and 2]] - With fitness belt. ==[[Wii U]]== *''[[Animal Crossing: Amiibo Festival]]'' Limited Edition — Bundled with Digby and Isabelle (Summer Outfit) amiibo. *''[[Guitar Hero Live]] Limited Edition — Comes with Guitar. *''[[Hyrule Warriors]] Limited Edition — Comes with Link's Scarf. *''[[The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker HD]] Limited Edition — Comes with Ganondorf figurine. *''[[The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD]] Limited Edition — Comes with Wolf Link amiibo. *''[[Lego City: Undercover]] Limited Edition — Bundled with Chase McCain Lego figure. *''[[Mario Kart 8]] Limited Edition — Bundled with Blue Shell plinth. *''[[Mario Party 10]] Limited Edition — Comes with Mario amiibo from the Super Mario range. *''[[Pokemon Rumble U]] Special Edition — Comes with either Black Kyurem or White Kyurem NFC Figure, collector's poster, one additional NFC Figure and download code for game. *''[[Pokken Tournament]] Limited Edition — Comes with Dark Mewtwo Amiibo Card and Pokken Tournament controller. *''[[Project Zero: Maiden of Black Water]] Limited Edition — Comes with double-sided poster, an art book, four Spirit Photographs, and a SteelBook™ software case. *''[[Rodea The Sky Soldier]] Limited Edition — Comes with hardcover official artbook, jewel case soundtrack and the exclusive Key of Time pendant, as well as the Nintendo Wii version of the game. *''[[Sing Party]] Limited Edition — Comes with Microphone. *''[[Splatoon]] Limited Edition — Comes with Inkling Squid amiibo. *''[[Star Fox Zero]] First Print Edition — Comes with Star Fox Guard. *''[[Super Mario Maker]] Amiibo Edition and Limited Edition — Comes with Classic Colours Mario amiibo and artbook/ just artbook. *''[[Super Smash Bros for Wii U]] Amiibo Edition / Limited Edition — Comes with CD Soundtrack and Mario amiibo from Super Smash Bros range / Soundtrack and Gamecube Controller adapter. *''[[Tokyo Mirage Sessions#FE]] Fortissimo Edition — Bundled with Artbook, Soundtrack and Lyrics. *''[[Wii Fit U]] Limited Edition and Balance Board Edition — Both editions come with pedometer. *''[[Wii Party U]] Limited Edition — Bundled with Wii Remote Plus White. *''[[Xenoblade Chronicles X]] Special Edition and Limited Edition — Comes with Artbook. *''[[Yoshi's Woolly World]] Limited Edition — Comes with Green Yarn Yoshi amiibo. *''[[ZombiU]] Limited Edition — Comes with Blood capsule surrounding the box. ==[[Xbox (console)|Xbox]]== *''[[Doom 3]]'' Collector's Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox.ign.com/objects/722/722339.html |title=IGN: Doom 3 (Limited Collector's Edition) |publisher=Xbox.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — metal keep case, full playable versions of ''[[Ultimate Doom]]'' and ''[[Doom II]]'' (with 2-4 player in deathmatch or co-op), interviews with the id development team, a G4 "Icons" behind-the-scenes featurette, and concept art of the game. Unlike the vanilla Doom 3 release, this version is not backwards compatible with the Xbox 360. *''[[Jade Empire]]'': Limited Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox.ign.com/objects/740/740561.html |title=IGN: Jade Empire (Limited Edition) |publisher=Xbox.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — a foil wrapper and unique cover, an extra character and other special content, new combat style, making-of video, demos of Microsoft Xbox games. *''[[MechAssault 2: Lone Wolf]]'' Limited Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox.ign.com/objects/712/712246.html |title=IGN: MechAssault 2: Lone Wolf (Limited Edition) |publisher=Xbox.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — foil wrapper cover, two exclusive multiplayer maps and a "making of" video feature. *''[[Mortal Kombat: Deception]]'' Kollector's Edition[http://xbox.gamezone.com/gamesell/p24616.htm Mortal Kombat: Deception Kollector's Edition - Xbox game] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070211121020/http://xbox.gamezone.com/gamesell/p24616.htm |date=February 11, 2007 }} — one of four different covers, a metal trading card, a bonus disc with a video of the history of the [[Mortal Kombat (series)|''Mortal Kombat'' series]], characters biographies and an "arcade perfect" version of the original ''[[Mortal Kombat (1992 video game)|Mortal Kombat]]''. *''[[True Crime: New York City]]'' Collector's Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox.ign.com/objects/787/787408.html |title=IGN: True Crime: New York City (Collector's Edition) |publisher=Xbox.ign.com |date=2005-11-16 |accessdate=2012-03-14}}— tin case, a bonus DVD with behind-the-scenes footage, making-of features, trailers, music and interviews, viral videos and gameplay fly-throughs, and a New York City map with game objectives. ==[[Xbox 360]]== *''[[Clive Barker's Jericho]]'' Special Edition — Contained SteelBook case with no slipcover. The Xbox logo is printed on the spine. *''[[Dead Space (video game)|Dead Space]]'': Ultra Limited Edition — Comes in special ultra limited edition packaging containing the game, [[Dead Space: Downfall]] Animated Movie, bonus content DVD, exclusive custom lithograph art illustrated and signed by Ben Templesmith, art book, graphic novel, and an Ishimura crew patch. Limited to only 1,000 copies and sold directly through the publishers online store.{{cite web|url=http://eastore.ea.com/DRHM/servlet/ControllerServlet?Action=DisplayProductDetailsPage&SiteID=ea&Locale=en_US&Env=BASE&productID=106790800 |title=EA Store: Dead Space Ultra Limited Edition |publisher=Eastore.ea.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817092958/http://eastore.ea.com/DRHM/servlet/ControllerServlet?Action=DisplayProductDetailsPage&SiteID=ea&Locale=en_US&Env=BASE&productID=106790800 |archivedate=2009-08-17 |df= }} *''[[Fable II]]'' Limited Collector's Edition — *''[[Fable III]]'' Limited Collector's Edition — Fable III game, gold coin with Fable emblem on both sides, deck of Fable playing cards, several DLC codes and a 24-hour Xbox Live code, all packaged in a large "Fable-style" book with Fable emblem on both sides. *''[[Forza Motorsport 2]]'' Limited Collector's Edition — Comes in a carbon fibre style bookcase and contains the game and manual, a 156-page book which details car manufactures, developer interviews and track strategies and a free code to unlock 3 bonus cars on Xbox Live. The cars are the Ferrari Challenge Stradale, the Saleen S218E and the Subaru Impreza S204 *''[[Forza Motorsport 3]]'' Limited Collector's Edition - A box containing opening with Slip Case,2 Bonus Content Disc, Game Play Disc, Forza Emblem Grey colored Sandisk USB, Forza metal Silver Keychain *''[[Forza Motorsport 4]]'' Limited Collector's Edition — A box containing a steelbook case, a bonus disc to download bonus extras, a vinyl sticker set with [[Turn 10 Studios]] logo and more, a 96-page book containing the cars and more, a code to unlock a free BMW Xbox Dashboard theme, and a code to unlock an additional 25 bonus cars, such as a 2012 BMW M5 for use in the game. *''[[Gears of War]]'' Limited Collector's Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.ign.com/objects/846/846370.html |title=IGN: Gears of War (Limited Collector's Edition) |publisher=Xbox360.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}}— a tin case, 'Destroyed Beauty' - the ''Gears of War'' hardbound art book, bonus DVD with an inside look at the making of ''Gears of War'', the 'Art of Gears of War' trailer, and 'Gears of War: The Race to E3'. Considered one of "the top ten console limited/special editions as tracked by The NPD Group through November 2007." *''[[Gears of War 2]]'' Limited Edition — a tin case, art book, making of DVD, photo of in-game characters Dom and Maria and Golden Lancer Assault Rifle code. *''[[Gears of War 3]]'' Limited Edition — A box containing a tin case, a COG flag that once flew at the House of Sovereigns, documents of Marcus Fenix's father Adam Fenix, and an Octus Medal that was awarded to Adam Fenix for his work on the Hammer of Dawn, engraved with a code to unlock Adam Fenix as a playable character in multiplayer. *''[[Gears of War 3]]'' Epic Edition — Contents included with the Limited Edition, including a Marcus Fenix statue, a 96-page artbook, and a code to unlock the Infected Omen Weapon Pack that includes multiplayer skins for the five starting weapons in the game. *''[[Lost Planet: Extreme Condition]]'' Collector's Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.ign.com/objects/859/859842.html |title=IGN: Lost Planet: Extreme Condition (Collector's Edition) |publisher=Xbox360.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — metal case with altered art, exclusive multiplayer map only available in Collector's Edition, exclusive art book, and bonus CD including the soundtrack, trailers, wallpapers, and digital art. Considered one of "the top ten console limited/special editions as tracked by The NPD Group through November 2007." *''[[Mass Effect (video game)|Mass Effect]]'' Limited Collector's Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.ign.com/objects/142/14208438.html |title=IGN: Mass Effect (Limited Collector's Edition) |publisher=Xbox360.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — tin case, artbook, a fiction book, and a DVD with exclusive video content about Mass Effect.. *''[[Perfect Dark Zero]]'' Limited Collector's Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.ign.com/objects/769/769929.html |title=IGN: Perfect Dark Zero (Limited Collector's Edition) |publisher=Xbox360.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — bonus 2nd DVD with in-depth behind-the-scenes feature, exclusive track 'Limelight' by DJ Kepi & Kat, PD:Z theme for Guide, first chapter of 'Perfect Dark: Initial Vector,' PD:Z gamer pictures for Live, an embossed metal DVD case, one of nine holographic Glyph cards, and the 'Hong Kong Sunrise' special edition comic booklet. *''[[Tales of Vesperia]]'' Special Edition{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/xbox360/rpg/talesofvesperia/news.html?sid=6195445&tag=result;title;2 |title=Namco Bandai Games America Reveals Tales of Vesperia Special Edition |publisher=GameSpot.com |date=2008-08-26 |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — Alternative box art by Kosuke Fujishima on a metal case, as well as additional pages to the manual with additional artwork, plus a soundtrack CD titled "Tales 10th Anniversary Volume 1" with 22 selected tracks from Tales of Vesperia and other past Tales games. "Tales 10th Anniversary Volume 2" was made available by use of the bonus code in April, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.talesrpg.com/special/ |title=Tales of the Abyss® and Tales of Graces™ | Namco Bandai Games America, INC |publisher=Talesrpg.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} *''[[Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six: Vegas]]'' Limited Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.ign.com/objects/864/864176.html |title=IGN: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six: Vegas (Limited Edition) |publisher=Xbox360.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — alternate box art and a second disc with 'The Making of Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Vegas', 'The Faking-of the Making-of', and additional bonus features. *''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Double Agent]]'' Limited Edition{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.ign.com/objects/856/856075.html |title=IGN: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Double Agent (Limited Collector's Edition) |publisher=Xbox360.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — special alternate case art, "Covert Ops" documentary focusing on authenticity & realism of the game, behind-the-scenes look at the making of the game, interview with [[Michael Ironside]], multiplayer tips & tactics, seven mini web films, game trailers, concept art gallery and more. Considered one of "the top ten console limited/special editions as tracked by The NPD Group through November 2007." *''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Conviction]]'' Collectors Edition – Contains Steelbook case, artbook, upper Echolon pass card/USB, and DLC codes. *''[[Transformers: The Game]]'' Cybertron Edition — Cybertron edition box art, making-of DVD, comic book, and codes to unlock the Cybertron level. *''[[Turning Point: Fall of Liberty]]'' Special Edition — Contained SteelBook case with no slipcover. The Xbox logo is printed on the spine. *''[[Viva Piñata]]''{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.ign.com/objects/856/856656.html |title=IGN: Viva Pinata (Special Edition) |publisher=Xbox360.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-14}} — first run copies come in a special rounded-top packaging, and includes a bonus disc. The Bonus disc includes the [[Viva Piñata (TV series)|''Viva Piñata'' TV series]] episode "Horstachio of a Different Color", a demo of ''[[Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy]]'' and demos of [[Xbox Live Arcade]] games ''[[Frogger]]'', ''[[Marble Blast Ultra]]'' and ''[[Time Pilot]]''. ==[[Xbox One]]== *''[[Forza 5]]'' Collector's Edition{{Cite web|url = http://www.microsoftstore.com/store/msusa/en_US/pdp/Forza-Motorsport-5-Limited-Edition-for-Xbox-One/productID.289733400|title = Forza Motorsport 5 Limited Edition for Xbox One|date = |accessdate = 2015-03-26|website = |publisher = Microsoft|last = |first = }} — *''[[Forza 5]]'' Paddock Edition — Contained a stainless steel water bottle, branded stem caps, a keychain, premium hoodie and optic sunglasses. Limited to 3,000 units.{{Cite web|url=http://store.forzamotorsport.net/forza-motorsport-5-paddock-edition.html |title=Forza Motorsport Store - Forza Motorsport 5 Paddock Edition |date= |accessdate=2015-01-13 |website= |publisher= |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150112234718/http://store.forzamotorsport.net/forza-motorsport-5-paddock-edition.html |archivedate=2015-01-12 |df= }} *''[[Killer Instinct (2013 video game)|Killer Instinct]]'' Pin Ultimate Edition — http://collectorsedition.org/game-db/killer-instinct-pin-ultimate-edition-xb1-americas ==External links== ''' [http://collectorsedition.org/ CollectorsEdition] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:Video game lists|Collector and Special Editions]] [[Category:Video game marketing]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Musical instruments in art]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Judith Leyster Merry Trio.jpg | title=''The Merry Trio'' | artist=[[Judith Leyster]] | year=1629 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=88 | width_metric=73.5 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=London & Maastricht | museum=Collection Noortman }}
'''''The Merry Trio''''' is an oil painting by [[Judith Leyster]] in the Collection Noortman.<ref name=Hofrichter>Judith Leyster: A Woman Painter in Holland's Golden Age, by Frima Fox Hofrichter, Doornspijk, 1989, Davaco Publishers, {{ISBN|90-70288-62-1}}, catalog #9</ref> It was considered a work by [[Frans Hals]] until 1903.
==Provenance== The painting was together with Leyster's ''[[The Last Drop by Leyster|The Last Drop]]'' in the collection of the British dealer/auction house Sir George Donaldson (1845-1925) where it was documented in 1903.<ref name=Hofrichter/> The two may be pendants, as they were then reported to have the same measurements.
According to Hofrichter, the scene shows the popular ''Merry company'' theme common in 17th-century ''commedia dell'arte'' plays.<ref name=Hofrichter/> This daylight scene serves as a contrast to its candlelit pendant which warns of the dangers of drinking and smoking. Clearly, Leyster preferred the sober yet festive daytime scene, because she selected the musician on the right to illustrate her [[Self-portrait by Judith Leyster|self-portrait]].
<gallery mode=packed widths="250" heights="250"> File:Judith Leyster Merry Trio.jpg File:Judith Leyster, Dutch (active Haarlem and Amsterdam) - The Last Drop (The Gay Cavalier) - Google Art Project.jpg </gallery>
==See also== *[[List of paintings by Judith Leyster]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1629 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Judith Leyster]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]]

page.title: Napoléon on the Battlefield of Eylau

revision.comment: added [[Category:Paintings about death]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Antoine-Jean Gros - Napoleon on the Battlefield of Eylau - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|upright=1.64|''Napoléon on the Battlefield of Eylau'']]
'''''Napoléon on the Battlefield of Eylau''''' ({{lang-fr|Napoléon sur le champ de bataille d'Eylau}}) is an [[oil painting]] of 1808 by French [[Romanticism|Romantic]] painter [[Antoine-Jean Gros]]. Completed during the winter of 1807–1808, the work has become an icon of the emerging style of [[Romanticism#Romantic visual arts|French Romanticism]]. It depicts a moment from the aftermath of the bloody [[Battle of Eylau]] (7–8 February 1807) in which [[Napoléon Bonaparte]] surveys the battlefield where his ''[[Grande Armée]]'' secured a costly victory against the Russians. Although ''Napoleon on the Battlefield of Eylau'' retains elements of [[history painting]], it is by far Gros's most realistic work depicting Napoleon and breaks from the subtlety of [[Neoclassicism]]. The painting's influence can be seen in the works of artists like [[Théodore Géricault]] and [[Eugène Delacroix]].
== Background == {{main|Battle of Eylau}} In early February 1807, the Russian army, under the command of [[Levin August von Bennigsen]], was in full retreat while being pursued by [[Napoléon Bonaparte]]'s ''[[Grande Armée]]''.<ref name=history>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofwar.org/articles/battles_eylau.html|title=Battle of Eylau|publisher=History of War|author=Rickard, J.|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> The field armies of Russia's ally, the [[Kingdom of Prussia]], had been decisively defeated by the ''Grande Armée'' at the double [[Battle of Jena–Auerstedt]] on 14 October 1806. This left the Russian army as the only major land force opposing Napoléon in the [[War of the Fourth Coalition]].<ref name=series>{{cite web|url=http://www.napoleon-series.org/military/organization/c_eylau.html#14|title=French Cavalry at Eylau, 1807 and Napoleon's Cavalry Doctrine|publisher=Napoleon Series|author=Beorn, Cadet|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> After some failed attempts to disrupt the French advance, Bennigsen decided to regroup his retreating forces at the Prussian village of Eylau (now [[Bagrationovsk]], [[Kaliningrad Oblast]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frenchempire.net/battles/eylau/|title=Battle of Eylau|publisher=French Empire|author=Jensen, Nathan D.|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
Fighting began in the afternoon of 7 February when Napoleon's baggage section arrived at Eylau in preparation for the Emperor's arrival, unaware of the Russian presence still in the village. Thinking the French were attempting to capture the village, Bennigsen sent reinforcements to Eylau; Napoléon reciprocated with his own fighting force. Intense engagements followed, especially around the village's church and cemetery, but the French held control of Eylau by the end of the day.<ref name=history/><ref name=series/>
The Russians countered in the early morning of 8 February with a massive [[artillery]] bombardment. On the brink of a disastrous defeat, Napoléon called upon the [[Reserve Cavalry Corps (Grande Armée)|Reserve Cavalry Corps]] to [[cavalry charge|charge]] the Russian columns approaching Eylau.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://warfarehistorynetwork.com/daily/military-history/napoleon-vs-russia-battle-of-eylau/|title=Napoleon Vs Russia: Battle of Eylau|publisher=Warfare History Network|author=Hawkins, Jenkins|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> It disrupted the Russian offensive long enough for the French lines to stabilize. By nightfall, Bennigsen ordered his forces to withdraw: the French, though able to declare a victory, were left with a snowy battlefield riddled with blood and frozen corpses.<ref name=series/>
== Commission == Napoléon sought to ensure that the victory at Eylau, though costly, would not be forgotten, entrusting the director of the [[Louvre]] [[Vivant Denon]] with commissioning an artist as a part of a much larger propaganda campaign.<ref name=foundation>{{cite web|url=https://www.napoleon.org/en/history-of-the-two-empires/paintings/napoleon-visiting-the-battlefield-at-eylau-9-february-1807/|title=NAPOLEON VISITING THE BATTLEFIELD AT EYLAU, 9 FEBRUARY, 1807|publisher=Napoleon Foundation|author=Huguenaud, Karine|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> One month after the battle, Denon announced a public competition for the commission: 26 artists sent in their sketches which were exhibited at the Louvre. [[Antoine-Jean Gros]] was declared the winner on 13 June, and completed ''Napoléon on the Battlefield of Eylau'' during the winter of 1807–1808.<ref name=foundation/> According to François de Vergnette, Denon stipulated much of what was to be featured in the painting, including "the moment to be depicted, the number of 'extras', the cadavers in the foreground, and the large format".<ref name=louvre>{{cite web|url=http://www.louvre.fr/en/oeuvre-notices/napoleon-battlefield-eylau|title=Napoleon at the Battle of Eylau|publisher=[[Louvre]]|author=Vergnette, François de|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
== Description == The painting portrays Napoleon arriving outside Eylau to survey the battlefield on 9 February 1807, the day after the fighting ended. The painting is on a monumental scale of 521 x 784 cm, such that most of the central figures are rendered life-sized.<ref name=web>{{cite web|url=http://www.wga.hu/html_m/g/gros/7eylau.html|title=Napoleon on the Battlefield of Eylau, 1807|publisher=Web Gallery of Art|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> Some of the figures on the edges of the painting are intentionally cut off to instil a feeling of the work being an actual fragment of a real-life scene. The viewer's attention is immediately drawn to the large pile of corpses in the foreground whose faces are twice life-sized; another soldier, wounded, cries out in a state of [[insanity|madness]].<ref name=louvre/><ref name=web/> According to the ''64th Grande Armée Bulletin'', the scene was designed "to instil in princes a love of peace and a horror of war".<ref name=foundation/>
In the center of the painting Napoléon is seen mounted on a light bay horse surveying the treatment of the wounded, his hand outstretched in a pose reminiscent of [[blessing]] the soldiers. "The consoling expression of the great man", wrote Denon, "seems to soften the horrors of death and spread a softer light on this scene of carnage".<ref name=foundation/> He is surrounded by members of his staff: [[Marshal Berthier]], [[Marshal Bessières]], and [[Auguste-Jean-Gabriel de Caulaincourt|General Caulaincourt]] are to the left, while [[Marshal Soult]], [[Marshal Davout]] and [[Marshal Murat]] flank on the right.<ref name=foundation/> A wounded Lithuanian soldier, taken aback by the compassion of the Emperor, pledges his allegiance to Napoléon while another former combatant embraces his leg.<ref name=louvre/>
== Reception and legacy ==
''Napoléon on the Battlefield of Eylau'' was first shown at the [[Paris Salon]] in 1809. Initially, some politicians suspected the painting aimed to portray the Emperor unfavorably, but Napoléon himself approved of Gros's work and presented him with the [[Légion d'honneur]] at the painter's award ceremony.<ref name=louvre/> Gros's depiction of Napoléon displayed a degree of realism not present in his earlier painting of the Emperor, ''[[Bonaparte Visiting the Plague Victims of Jaffa]]'' (1804), nor those by any other artist. In its portrayal of the unpleasant truth of war, ''Napoléon on the Battlefield of Eylau'' breaks with the prevailing style of [[Neoclassicism]] and was an early landmark in the emerging [[Romanticism|Romantic movement]].<ref name=louvre/> Its influence is apparent in the works of French artists like [[Théodore Géricault]] and [[Eugène Delacroix]], themselves both pioneers of Romanticism.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Antoine-Jean-Gros|title=Antoine Jean-Gros|work=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:1808 paintings]] [[Category:French paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of Napoleon]] [[Category:Paintings of the Louvre by French artists]] [[Category:Romantic paintings]] [[Category:War paintings]] [[Category:Paintings about death]]

revision.comment: needs ck for possible sourcing
revision.text:
The '''peer jury process''' is often used in the arts to assess applications for grants, proposals for exhibitions made in response to an open call for submissions and art competitions. Like the practice of [[peer review]] used in the academic sphere, a peer jury brings to an evaluation process expertise that an organization or agency awarding grants or sponsoring a competition might not itself have.
A peer jury in the arts context is generally composed of artists selected to be representative of those working in a relevant discipline or area. While jurors are expected to have [[independence]], [[anonymity]] is less of a concern than in academic [[peer review]], in part because the jury's task is not to catch errors or offer criticism but to only to select. For example, in Canada, agencies that award grants typically publish lists of jurors or make lists available on request.
In principle the peer jury process is an effective way for arts councils and other agencies to be responsive to and engaged with the constituencies they serve, and in touch with the latest developments in contemporary art.
==See also==
* [[peer review]]
[[Category:Arts councils]]

revision.comment: removed notability flag. ample proof of notability through citations.
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=[[File:Rhythm_of_Structure_Mathematics,_Art_and_Poetic_Reflection_Bowery_and_Beyond_catalog_cover_illustration_graphic,_Antioch_College_Herndon_Gallery,_2011.jpg]] | caption=Rhythm of Structure Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection: Bowery and Beyond catalog cover illustration graphic, 2011 | backcolor= | painting_alignment= | image_size= | title=Rhythm of Structure | artist= | year=2003 {{ndash}} present | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= | museum=Fire Patrol #5 Gallery, Wilmer Jennings Gallery, [[Bowery Poetry Club]], [[Ringling College of Art and Design]], [[Antioch College]], [[Museum of Science & Industry (Tampa)|Museum of Science & Industry]] | website = [http://www.rhythmofstructure.com rhythmofstructure.com] }}
'''''Rhythm of Structure''''' is a multimedia interdisciplinary project founded in 2003. It features a series of exhibitions, performances, and academic projects that explore the interconnecting structures and process of [[mathematics and art]], and language, as way to advance a movement of mathematical expression across the arts, across creative collaborative communities celebrating the rhythm and patterns of both ideas of the mind and the physical reality of nature.
==Introduction== ''Rhythm of Structure'', as an expanding series of art exhibitions, performances, videos/films and publications created and curated by multimedia mathematical artist and writer [[John Sims (artist)|John Sims]], explores and celebrates the intersecting [[structure]]s of mathematics, art, community, and nature.<ref name="nature">{{cite journal|title=Q&A: John Sims on mathematical art|journal=Nature|date=15 April 2010|volume=464|page=983|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/464983a.pdf?origin=ppub|accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="bombmagazine">{{cite web |author1=A.M. Weaver |title=John Sims by A.M. Weaver |url=https://bombmagazine.org/articles/john-sims/ |website=BOMB |accessdate=12 June 2018 |date=11 September 2009}}</ref> Sims also created ''Recoloration Proclamation'' featuring the installation, [[The Proper Way to Hang a Confederate Flag]] (2004).<ref>{{cite web|title=John Sims|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/author/john-sims-|website=HuffPost|accessdate=29 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=John Sims|url=https://bombmagazine.org/articles/john-sims/|website=Bomb|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref>
From his catalog essay from the ''Rhythm of Structure: Mathematics, Art and Poetic exhibition'', Sims sets the curatorial theme where he writes: "Mathematics, as a parameter of human consciousness in an indispensable conceptual technology, essential is seeing beyond the retinal and knowing beyond the intuitive. The language and process of mathematics, as elements of, foundation for art, inform an analytic expressive condition that inspires a visual reckoning for a convergence: from the illustrative to the metaphysical to the poetic. And in the dialectic of visual art call and text performative response, there is an inter-dimensional conversation where the twisting structures of language, vision and human ways give birth to the spiritual lattice of a social geometry, a community constructivism -- a place of connections, where emotional calculations meet spirited abstraction." <ref>{{cite book|author1=John Sims|title=Rhythm of Structure Catalogue - A John Sims Project|date=Oct 8, 2011|publisher=Selby Gallery, Ringling College of Art and Design|page=7|url=https://issuu.com/mathartist/docs/testcata1|accessdate=20 May 2018}}</ref>
First premiering at the Fire Patrol No.5 Gallery in 2003, with the show ''Rhythm of Structure: MathArt'' in [[Harlem]]. This interdisciplinary project has featured numerous exhibitions around the country collaborating with many notable artists, writers, and musicians including: [[Sol Lewitt]], [[Adrian Piper]], [[Dorothea Rockburne]], [[Alvin D. Loving|Al Loving]],[[Joe Overstreet]], [[Howardena Pindell]], [[Helaman Ferguson]], [[John A. Hiigli|John Hiigli]], [[Vandorn Hinnant]], [[Karen Finley]], [[Dread Scott]], [[DJ Spooky|Paul D. Miller]], [[Bob Holman]], Kate Rushin, [[Roman Verostko]], Joan Waltemath, [[Tara Betts]], [[Brent Collins]], Mike Field, Kazmier Maslanka, Ken Hiratsuka, Yael Acher Moriano, [[Richard Kostelanetz]], [[Kristin Prevallet]], John Sims, and former U.S. Poet Laureate [[Mark Strand]].<ref name="bathshebagrossman">{{cite web |title=Shows |url=https://www.bathsheba.com/artist/shows.html |website=Bathsheba Sculpture |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="agnesdenes">{{cite web |title=Exhibitions |url=http://www.agnesdenesstudio.com/exhibitions.html |website=Agnes Denes |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref>
In addition to the exhibitions, another major aim of ''Rhythm of Structure'' is the building of a interdisciplinary creative community around the intersection of mathematics and all forms of art, as it might inspire new art, innovation art and mathematics education, and increased respect and understanding of the [[rhythm]] and structure of nature itself. Such community experiences are created through call and response performances, social media and special video music projects such as The Rhythm of Structure and The Pi Day Anthem featuring John Sims and Vi Hart .<ref name="ams">{{cite web|title=Rhythm of Structure: Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection|url=http://www.ams.org/news?news_id=1085|website=American Mathematical Society|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Pi Day Anthem: Mathematics, Art and Beyond|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/john-sims-/pi-day-mathematics-art-an_b_9411708.html|website=HuffPost|accessdate=20 May 2018}}</ref>
==Background== Rhythm of Structure has its beginnings in Sims’ work as one of the international curators for the exhibition ''Science in the Arts - Art in the Sciences'', a city wide exhibition, in conjunction with the [[UNESCO#General Conference|UNESCO-ICSU World Conference of Science]], [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]] in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science in the Arts - Art in the Sciences|url=https://www.d.umn.edu/~ddunham/artsci.html|website=Doug Dunham|accessdate=20 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=A World of Science|journal=UNESCO|date=Oct 2002|volume=1|issue=1|page=6|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0013/001307/130715e.pdf|accessdate=20 May 2018}}</ref>
This led to the exhibition, ''MathArt/ArtMath'', curated by John Sims (then Coordinator of Mathematics at Ringling)<ref>{{cite web|title=Artist John Sims to explore correlation between quilting, math, community|url=http://newsroom.unl.edu/releases/2014/10/23/Artist+John+Sims+to+explore+correlation+between+quilting,+math,+community|website=University of Nebraska-Lincoln|accessdate=20 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Acclaimed "Math Artist" John Sims to speak at Texas State|url=http://www.txstate.edu/news/news_releases/news_archive/2005/04/Sims041105.html|website=Texas State|accessdate=20 May 2018}}</ref> and Kevin Dean, at the Selby Gallery [[Ringling College of Art and Design]] in 2002.<ref name="creativeloafing">{{cite web |title=Numbers Man |url=https://www.cltampa.com/arts-entertainment/article/20721530/numbers-man |website=Creative Loafing Tampa Bay |accessdate=11 June 2018 |date=21 Nov 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Contemporary Art And The Mathematical Instinct |date=2004 |publisher=Tweed Museum Of Art, University of Minnesota |page=36 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iLPpAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Mathart/artmath%22&dq=%22Mathart/artmath%22|isbn=9781889523279 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Artist John Sims not coming to campus, but exhibit still planned at Gettysburg College |url=http://www.gettysburg.edu/news_events/press_release_detail.dot?id=806fcc2d-7ed5-4338-bdbc-67845b9a648e |website=News @ Gettysburg |accessdate=13 June 2018 |date=30 Aug 2004}}</ref> This show presented a general survey of art inspired and framed by mathematics ideas of mostly American [[Modern art|modern]] and [[Contemporary art|contemporary]] artists, as well as mathematicians working in the area of visual mathematics. The theme of the show was designed to examine the complexity and diversity of the meaning of [[Mathematics and art|mathematical art]].<ref name="creativeloafing" /> The ''MathArt/ArtMath'' exhibition featured: [[Josef Albers]], [[Thomas Banchoff]], [[Richard Anuszkiewicz]], Manuelo Baez, [[Jhane Barnes]], [[Max Bill]], [[Mel Bochner]], [[Brent Collins]], David Davis, [[George Deem]], [[Agnes Denes]], [[M.C. Escher]], [[Fred Eversley]], Shannon Fagan, [[Helaman Ferguson]], Mike Field, [[Charles Gaines (artist)|Charles Gaines]], Paulus Gerdes, [[Bathsheba Grossman]], [[Al Held]], [[John A. Hiigli|John Hiigli]], Slavik Jablan, [[Alfred Jensen]], Andrienne Klein, [[Sol LeWitt]], [[Arthur Loeb|Arthur Lee Loeb]], [[DJ Spooky|Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky]], [[Marlena Novak]], [[Joe Overstreet]], [[Howardena Pindell]], [[Richard Wilbur|Richard Purdy]], [[Tony Robbin]], [[Dorothea Rockburne]], Frank Rothkamm, Irene Rousseau, [[Carlo Sequin]], John Sims, John Sullivan, [[Jack Tworkov]], [[Roman Verostko]], and John Waltemath.<ref name="carlosequin">{{cite web |title=Art Displays & Exhibits That Carlo Séquin participated in: |url=https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~sequin/BIO/exhibits.html |website=Berkley |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="bathshebagrossman" /><ref name="agnesdenes" /> There was a brochure and video produced for this exhibition.<ref>{{cite book |title=Mathart/artmath |date=2002 |publisher=Selby Gallery, Ringling School of Art and Design |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Mathart_artmath.html?id=dwXRYgEACAAJ}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=14th Annual Saratosa Film Festival |url=http://www.sarasotafilmfestival.com/images/SARASOTA_FILM_FESTIVAL_SFF_2012_Press_Release_SFF_APPROVED.pdf |website=Saratosa Film Festival |accessdate=13 June 2018 |date=2012}}</ref>
After the ''MathArt/ArtMath'' exhibition, Sims began working on a text about the nature of mathematical art leading to his chapter, ''Trees, Roots and a Brain: A Metaphorical Foundation for Mathematical Art'', in the book ''Mathematics and Culture II: Visual Perfection: Mathematics and Creativity''. In his chapter, he presents his ideas on the interconnection of mathematics, [[Environmental art|art and nature]], setting the stage for his next group of exhibitions called ''Rhythm of Structure''.<ref>{{cite book |title=Mathematics and Culture II |date=2005 |publisher=Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg |isbn=978-3-540-26443-9 |pages=163–170 |url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F3-540-26443-4_14 |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref>
==Exhibitions==
===''Rhythm of Structure:'' MathArt in Harlem (2003) === ''MathArt in Harlem'', January 2003, Fire Patrol #5 Gallery in [[Harlem]] [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], featured artists Audrey Bennet, Brent Collins, [[Agnes Denes]], [[Helaman Ferguson]], [[Charles Gaines (artist)|Charles Gaines]], [[Bathsheba Grossman]], [[John A. Hiigli|John Hiigli]], Ken Hiratsuka, Adrienne Klein, [[Sol LeWitt]], John Little, [[Alvin D. Loving|Al Loving]], [[Marlena Novak]], [[Joe Overstreet]], [[Howardena Pindell]], John Powell, [[Tony Robbin]], Irene Rousseau, Clifford Singer, John Sims, and Joan Waltemath.<ref name="bathshebagrossman" /><ref name="agnesdenes" />
===''Rhythm of Structure:'' The Mathematical Aesthetic (2004)===
''The Mathematical Aesthetic'', 2004, Wilmer Jennings Gallery in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], included artists: [[Joe Overstreet]], [[John T. Biggers|John Biggers]], Brent Collins, [[Lisa Corinne Davis]], [[Fred Eversley]], Terri Foster, [[Charles Gaines (artist)|Charles Gaines]], Simon Gouverneur, James Little, [[Alvin D. Loving|Al Loving]], [[Vandorn Hinnant]], Scott Johnson, [[Howardena Pindell]], John Sims, Kevin Sipp, [[Al Smith]], Joyce Wellman, and [[Jack White]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Joe Overstreet |url=https://hammer.ucla.edu/now-dig-this/artists/joe-overstreet/ |website=UCLA Hammer |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Joe Overstreet Innovation of Flight: Paintings 1967-1972 |date=2018 |publisher=Eric Firestone Press |isbn=9780984471546 |page=68}}</ref>
===''Rhythm of Structure:'' Beyond the Mathematics (2007)=== In association with the ''Knotting Mathematics and Art: Conference in Low Dimensional Topology and Mathematical Art'' at [[University of South Florida]] in November 2007, there were three exhibitions of ''Rhythm of Structure: Beyond the Mathematics'', curated by John Sims, which were hosted at the Centre Gallery, [[Museum of Science & Industry (Tampa)|Museum of Science & Industry]] in [[Tampa]], and the Oliver Gallery, respectively. Featured artists for this exhibition included: Davide Cervone, Brent Collins, Alex Feingold, [[Helaman Ferguson]], Mike Field, Nat Friedman, [[Chaim Goodman-Strauss]], Gary Greenfield, [[Bathsheba Grossman]], [[George W. Hart]], Slavik Jablan, [[Sol Lewitt]], [[Charles O. Perry]], [[Tony Robbin]], Radmilla Sazdanovic, John Sims, [[Carlo Sequin]], and Peter Swedenborg.<ref>{{cite web|title=Knotting Mathematics and Art: Conference in Low Dimensional Topology and Mathematical Art|url=http://knotart.cas.usf.edu/|website=University of South Florida|accessdate=29 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Rhythm of Structure: Beyond the Mathematics |url=http://knotart.cas.usf.edu/graphicSite/exhibition.html |website=USF University of Southern Florida |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref>
A review of the conference and exhibition was also published in the ''Journal of Mathematics and the Arts''.<ref name="knottingpaper">{{cite journal |title=Knotting Mathematics and Art: Conference in Low Dimensional Topology and Mathematical Art, University of South Florida, Tampa, FL, 1–4 November 2007 |journal=Journal of Mathematics and the Arts |date=20 Nov 2008 |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=47–51 |url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/17513470801977553 |accessdate=11 June 2018|doi=10.1080/17513470801977553 |last1=Hart |first1=George W |last2=Jonoska |first2=Natasha }}</ref>
===''Rhythm of Structure:'' Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection at Bowery Poetry Club (2009-10)=== ''Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection'', 2009-2010, premiered at the [[Bowery Poetry Club]] in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref name="ams" /><ref name="guernica">{{cite web|title=John Sims: Celebrating Pi Day with a Political Math Artist|url=https://www.guernicamag.com/john-sims-celebrating-pi-day-with-math-and-art/|website=Guernica|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="SelbyCatalog">{{cite book|title=Rhythm of Structure|date=Oct 8, 2011|publisher=Selby Gallery, Ringling College of Art and Design|location=Saratosa, Florida|url=https://issuu.com/mathartist/docs/testcata1|accessdate=29 April 2018|isbn=978-0-615-48847-9}}</ref> This exhibition consisted of nine shows, each show a month long typically featuring two artists or a small group. Featured poets or performers were invited to respond to the works with a performance at the closing of the show.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://theweeklychallenger.com/john-sims-conceptual-artist-challenges-conventional-conversations-about-history-racism-and-love/|title=John Sims: Conceptual artist challenges conventional conversations about history, racism and love {{!}}|website=theweeklychallenger.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref> The entire exhibition featured over 70 artists and performers, plus an art class from [[Brooklyn Academy of Science and the Environment]], and students of the Rhythm of Structure Class at NYU [[Tisch School of the Arts]]. The complete exhibition led to a published catalog and documentary film, which screened at the [[Sarasota Film Festival]] in 2012. The entire exhibition then traveled as a summary show to [[Ringling College of Art and Design]], as well as [[Antioch College]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Math Points to Art and Poetry in New York's Bowery This Fall|url=https://www.maa.org/news/math-news/math-points-to-art-and-poetry-in-new-yorks-bowery-this-fall|website=Mathematical Association of America|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="guernica" />
'''''Squares and Circles'' featuring John Hiigli and Vandorn Hinnant'''
This inaugural show featured the duet paintings: ''Chrome 163'' by [[John A. Hiigli|John Hiigli]], and ''What Euclid intended for us to know'' by [[Vandorn Hinnant]]. Responding poems/poets: ''Circular Vibration'' by Christina Schmitt, ''The Digital Organic'' by Alan Gilbert, ''The Square Transformed'' by Christina Schmitt, and ''Poemedy Squircular'' (Excerpt) by Summer Hill Seven.<ref name="SelbyCatalog" />
'''''Lines and Curves'' featuring Paulus Gerdes/John Sims and Ken Hiratsuka '''
This show featured rope installation and stone carving: ''A Roped Mirrored Curve'' by Paulus Gerdes/John Sims, ''Chained Universe'' by Ken Hiratsuka. Responding poems/poets: ''Quadrants'' by [[Kristin Prevallet]], ''Images of Devonian Age'' by Pooh Kaye, and ''The Curvature of Green'' by [[Shanxing Wang]].<ref name="SelbyCatalog" />
'''''The Cartesian MathArt Hive'' featuring The Hive Artists '''
''The Cartesian MathArt Hive'' created by John Sims based on the rotations of his piece ''SquareRoots of a Tree'' in a collaboration of the following works: ''Haloed Angel Study: Spark'' by [[Dorothea Rockburne]], ''Eseau on Globe Crossing'' by Joyce Wellman, ''Chrome 151: 3 Spheres'' by [[John A. Hiigli|John Hiigli]] , ''Isometric Systems in Isotropic Space-Map Projection: The Cube'' by [[Agnes Denes]], ''Square Roots of a Tree'' by John Sims, ''Squaring the Circle: Heaven in Earth'' by Pam Tuczyn, ''Drawing 13'' by [[Roman Verostko]], ''Poincare-double lace'' by [[Carlo H. Séquin|Carlo Sequin]], ''Iterations'' by Mike Field, ''Enlightened Vision #10'' by Christina Schmitt, ''Kelien-Fountain'' by Davide Cevone, ''Root Three Fractal SpiralGram'' by [[Vandorn Hinnant]], ''Zero'' by Kevin Dean, ''Tree Root of a Fractal'' by John Sims, ''Spheres'' by Susan Happersett, ''Fish'' by Ken Hiratsuka, ''Drawn with a Compass, Chopstick and a Pen'' by [[Howardena Pindell]], ''Our Days are Numbered!'' by Robert Fitterman, ''Mapping of the Universe'' by Faybiene Miranda, ''Is Numerology Math'' by Chris Funkhouser, ''Where Come Together'' by Chris Funkhouser, ''Alphabetical Mutability'' by Tatiana Bonch, and ''One'' by Marcella Durand.<ref name="SelbyCatalog" />
''The Cartesian MathArt Hive'' was also featured in a ''Journal of Mathematics and Arts'' paper.<ref name="cartesianmathhivepaper">{{cite journal |author1=Susan Happersett |title=The Cartesian MathArt Hive Exhibition, The Bowery Poetry Club, New York, 2009–2010 |journal=Journal of Mathematics and the Arts |date=16 Apr 2010 |volume=4 |issue=3 |pages=163–172 |doi=10.1080/17513472.2010.490756 |url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17513472.2010.490756 |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref>
'''''You Lie'' featuring Paul D. Miller and Dread Scott '''
This exhibition featured the digital works on paper, ''You Lie'' by [[DJ Spooky|Paul D. Miller]] and ''Poll Dance'' by [[Dread Scott]]. Responding Poems/Poets: ''Spam A Lot (Viagra for Joe Wilson)'' by LaTasha N. Nevada Diggs, ''Survey'' by LaTasha N. Nevada Diggs, ''Coolant System'' by Alan Gilbert, and ''Count Me In'' by Kelly Zen-Yie Tsai.<ref name="SelbyCatalog" />
'''''The Square Root of Love'' featuring Karen Finley and John Sims '''
This duet show featured: ''Many Moods of Love'' by [[Karen Finley]] and ''Square Root of Love'' by John Sims. Responding Poems/Poets:''The Square Root of Love: Calculating the HEART of Things'' by JoAnne Growney, and ''Learning To Be My Father's Son or 16 Things I Could Never Tell My Father'' by [[Regie Cabico]].<ref name="SelbyCatalog" /><ref>{{cite web |title=THE SQUARE ROOT OF LOVE |url=http://sarasota.festivalgenius.com/2012/films/thesquarerootofloveevent_sarasota2012_sarasota2012 |website=Saratosa Film Festival 2012 |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref>
John Sims' part of exhibition developed into a Valentine's Day wine-poetry-film project premiering in Paris in 2017.<ref>{{cite web |title=Square Root Of Love |url=https://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/3327087?&cookie_header=1 |website=Brown Paper Tickets |accessdate=14 June 2018 |date=16 Aug 2013}}</ref>
'''''Selected Infinite Extensions Arbitrarily Constrained'' featuring Sol LeWitt and Adrian Piper'''
''Selected Infinite Extensions Arbitrarily Constrained'' featuring [[Sol LeWitt]] and [[Adrian Piper]] was a duet show that featured the wall installations: ''Drawing #163'' by [[Sol LeWitt]], and ''Vanishing Point #1'' by [[Adrian Piper]]. Responding Poems/Poets: ''Sociedad Anonima'' by Mónica de la Torre, ''Two Poems Squared'' by [[Bob Holman]], ''Dear Morning Light dear visiwind'' by [[Bob Holman]], ''Terra Quad'' by [[Edwin Torres (poet)|Edwin Torres]], ''MathArtPoem: A LeWitt/Piper Response'' by John Sims/Rhythm of Structure Class/NYU, ''For the Girl Who Was Asked to Write a Poem About Me and, as Usual, Wanted to Write a Poem About Her Heart Instead'' by Eboni Hogan, ''The Elevator'' by Mark Strand, and ''Empty'' by Jon Sands.<ref name="SelbyCatalog" />
''Selected Infinite Extensions Arbitrarily Constrained'' was reviewed by ''[[Art in America]] Magazine''.<ref name="artistsdothemath">{{cite web|author1=John Reed|title=Artists Do the Math|url=https://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-features/news/adrian-piper-john-sims-mark-strand-bowery/|website=Art in America|accessdate=24 May 2018|date=24 Mar 2010}}</ref>
'''''(20, 21, 29): An Assignment'' featuring the Students of Brooklyn Academy of Science and Environment'''
''(20, 21, 29): An Assignment,'' a visualization of the [[Pythagorean triple]] (20, 21, 29) created by art students with teacher Jennifer Lemish at the [[Brooklyn Academy of Science and the Environment]].<ref>{{cite web |title=20, 21, 29: A John Sims Assignment Installation |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_MJTjJoxxlo&NR=1 |website=YouTube |accessdate=13 June 2018 |date=6 June 2010}}</ref> Responding Poems/Poets: ''21 Reasons Why I hate Math'' by Shappy Seasholtz, and ''29 Solutions For Writers, by People Who Know Better Than Me'' by [[Cristin O'Keefe Aptowicz]].<ref name="SelbyCatalog" />
'''''Mathematical Graffiti'' featuring Fernando Mora, John Sims with Kyle Goen, Mark Turgeon, and the Bowery Poetry Club Patrons'''
''Mathematical Graffiti'' featured: Fernando Mora, John Sims with Kyle Goen, Mark Turgeon, and the Bowery Poetry Club Patrons. Poetic Responses: ''Mutually Inverse Operations: Mathematical Poetry on the Occasion of the Mathematical Graffiti Wall'' by Gregory Vincent St. Thomasino, ''Proportional Poems'' by Kaz Maslanka, ''Graffiti Mathemaku'' by [[Bob Grumman]], ''33 Symmetry Axes x 40 Orthogonal Triples: or, Free Will, Revisited'' by [[Stephanie Strickland]], ''Who Counts, Counts'' by [[Stephanie Strickland]], and ''Notes on Numbers'' by [[Richard Kostelanetz]].<ref name="SelbyCatalog" />
Gregory Vincent St. Thomasino featured portions of this exhibition in his blog.<ref name="GregoryVincentStThomasino">{{cite web |author1=Gregory Vincent St. Thomasino |title=Thursday, April 29, 2010 |url=http://eratio.blogspot.com/2009/10/e.html?m=1 |website=E-Ratio |accessdate=3 June 2018 |date=29 April 2010}}</ref>
'''''The HyperQuilt'' featuring Helen Beamish, Elaine Ellison, Suzanne Gould, John Sims, Ella Toy, Diana Venters, and Paula Wynter'''
''The HyperQuilt'' featured: Helen Beamish, Elaine Ellison, Suzanne Gould, John Sims, Ella Toy, Diana Venters, and Paula Wynter. Responding Poems/Poets: ''The Language of Quilts'' by [[Tara Betts]], ''The Last Time'' by Adam Falkner and Jeanann Verlee, ''We Come From Farm People'' by Kate Rushin, ''The Math Poem: Along The Learning Curve'' by Kate Rushin.<ref name="SelbyCatalog" />
'''''Rhythm of Structure:'' Bowery and Beyond (2011)'''
The entire nine ''Rhythm of Structure'' shows at the Bowery Poetry Club were brought together as one united ''Rhythm of Structure: Bowery and Beyond'' exhibition at the Selby Gallery at Ringling College of Art and Design in February, 2011.<ref>{{cite web |title=Insider: Art |url=https://www.sarasotamagazine.com/articles/2011/2/1/insider-art |website=Saratosa Magazine |accessdate=12 June 2018 |date=10 Feb 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Poetry and art merge with math at Ringling College |url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/LK/20110220/News/605185767/SH/ |website=Herald Tribune |accessdate=12 June 2018 |date=20 Feb 2011}}</ref>
After the Selby Gallery showing at Ringling, it was shown later that year at the [[Antioch College]], from May to November 2011.<ref>{{cite web |title=Exhibition at Antioch College Explores Mathematics through the Arts |url=http://www.antiochcollege.edu/news/archive/exhibition-antioch-college-explores-mathematics-through-arts |website=Antioch College |accessdate=12 June 2018 |date=11 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Antioch College hosts closing symposium for 'Rhythm of Structure' exhibition |url=https://www.antiochcollege.edu/news/archive/antioch-college-hosts-closing-symposium-rhythm-structure-exhibition |website=Antioch College |accessdate=12 June 2018 |date=21 Oct 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=John Sims exhibit to open at Antioch College |url=https://ysnews.com/news/2011/05/john-sims-exhibit-to-open-at-antioch-college |website=YSNews |accessdate=12 June 2018 |date=20 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Closing events for Sims art exhibit|url=http://ysnews.com/news/2011/11/closing-events-for-john-sims-art-exhibit|website=YSNews.com|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref> The ''[[Dayton City Paper]]'' reviewed the exhibition and featured an article in their local newspaper.<ref name="saratosaheraldtribune">{{cite web |author1=Marty Fugate |title=Rhythm of Structure: Bowery and Beyond |url=http://ticket.heraldtribune.com/2012/04/12/rhythm-of-structure-bowery-and-beyond/ |website=Herald Tribune |accessdate=3 June 2018 |date=12 April 2012}}</ref>
==Publications==
'''''Rhythm of Structure Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection: Bowery and Beyond - Exhibition Catalogue'' '''
In 2011, the catalog ''Rhythm of Structure Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection: Bowery and Beyond'' was produced by Selby Gallery and [[Antioch College]] Herndon Gallery at [[Ringling College of Art and Design]] and John Sims, containing all 9 of the ''Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection'' exhibits.<ref name="SelbyCatalog" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Exhibition at Antioch College Explores Mathematics through the Arts|url=http://www.antiochcollege.edu/news/archive/exhibition-antioch-college-explores-mathematics-through-arts|website=Antioch College|accessdate=29 April 2018}}</ref> ''Sarasota Herald Tribune'' previewed and reviewed the exhibition catalog at Selby Gallery, and the film at the Sarasota Film Festival.<ref name="saratosaheraldtribune"/>
'''''Rhythm of Structure:'' MathArt in the African Diaspora - International Review of African American Art '''
In 2004, John Sims and Juliette Harris co-edited a special issue, ''MathArt in the African Diaspora'', for the ''International Review of African American Art'' which featured artists: John Sims, [[Al Smith]], Juliette Harris, [[Ron Eglash]], Brent Collins, Andrea Pollan, [[Howardena Pindell]], and Paulus Gerdes.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Visual forms in our rhythms: Introduction to Rhythm of Structure: MathArt in African Diaspora|journal=International Review of African American Art|date=January 2004|volume=19|issue=3|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298871365_Visual_forms_in_our_rhythms_Introduction_to_Rhythm_of_Structure_MathArt_in_African_Diaspora|accessdate=29 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=The International Review of African American Art|title=Rhythm of Structure MathArt in the African Diaspora|volume=3|issue=19.3|url=http://iraaa.museum.hamptonu.edu/store/Details.cfm?ProdID=72&category=|accessdate=29 April 2018}}</ref>
==NYU course== In the spring of 2010, in connection to the ''Rhythm of Structure: Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection'' at the Bowery Poetry Club, John Sims was invited to teach a course for the department of Art and Public Policy at [[Tisch School of the Arts]]. The course, "Rhythm of Structure: Trees, Flags and Clock", examined the mechanisms/structures of developing John Sims' three large-scale interdisciplinary art projects (as case studies), which explored issues of social justice, community building, and the politics of grand scale works. With these multi-level projects-in-progress, which intersect the space of art with mathematics, visual politics, and social networking, the course investigated the various strategies and challenges in creating a system of objects-texts-sounds-works that employs the tools of social organizing, media, technology, [[culture jamming]], performance, poetry, and satire.<ref>{{cite web |title=Art & Public Policy: Past Courses |url=http://tisch.nyu.edu/art-public-policy/courses/course-archive |website=NYU Tisch |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="youtubestructureclass">{{cite web |title=MathArtPoem by John Sims and Rhythm of Structure Class |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MGFdqHEGA9U |website=YouTube |accessdate=3 June 2018}}</ref>
The student final group project was a collective video-poetry response to the [[Sol Lewitt]] and [[Adrian Piper]] exhibition, ''Selected Infinite Extensions Arbitrarily Constrained'', which was up at that point at the ''Rhythm of Structure'' exhibition at the Bowery Poetry Club.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bowery Poetry Club presents Sol LeWitt and Adrian Piper |url=http://www.e-artnow.org/index.php?id=296&tx_rtgcreator_pi1%5Bcommand%5D=ACTION&tx_rtgcreator_pi1%5Buid%5D=3438 |website=e-Art Now |accessdate=3 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Biography |url=https://www.paulacoopergallery.com/artists/estate-of-sol-lewitt/biography |website=Paula Cooper Gallery |accessdate=3 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Sol Lewitt's Biography |url=http://www.alfonsoartiaco.com/web/index.cfm?id=B5DDE381-AC7F-463F-890EFC9CB290622E |website=Alfonso Artiaco |accessdate=3 June 2018}}</ref> The video and live student readings were also presented at the closing of the show.<ref name="youtubestructureclass" />
==Film== ''Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection'' was made into a documentary, ''Rhythm of Structure: Bowery and Beyond'',<ref>{{cite web |title=Rhythm of Structure: Bowery and Beyond (1:11:45) |url=https://www.imdb.com/videoplayer/vi876061721 |website=IMDB |accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Rhythm of Structure: Bowery and Beyond (2011) |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2198536/plotsummary?ref_=tt_ov_pl |website=IMDB |accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref> and presented at [[Sarasota Film Festival]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rhythm of Structure: Bowery and Beyond|url=http://ticket.heraldtribune.com/2012/04/12/rhythm-of-structure-bowery-and-beyond/|website=Herald Tribune: Ticket Saratosa|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref> The film was also previewed and reviewed by the ''Saratosa Herald Tribune''.<ref name="saratosaheraldtribune" /><ref>{{cite web |title=(Alma Sue's Quilts)|url=http://www.almasue.com/creative-journeys.htm |website=Alma Sue's Quilts |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref>
In connection to the film screening, there was are dinner, art performance reception featuring John Sims and Karen Finley's Square of Love installation from the Rhythm of Structure exhibition at the Bowery Poetry Club. The dinner featured a special menu prepared by Chef Gene Marra inspired by roots and love. The performance program included Twinkle, the late Kenny Drew Jr., Thomas Carabasi, Eleonora Lvov, Nate Jacobs, Michael Mendez, Kyleelise Holmes, Greg Tate and Bahiyyah Maroon.<ref name="SQR Magazine">{{cite web |title=John Sims "brings It" With the Square Root of Love |url=https://srqbacklot.com/2012/04/20/john-sims-brings-it-with-the-square-root-of-love/ |website=SRQ Backlot |author=SQR Magazine|accessdate=16 June 2018 |date=20 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=LoveCabaret/CafePalm/JohnSims |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qrBIFk_6LLk |website=YouTube |accessdate=16 June 2018 |date=21 May 2012}}</ref>
==Reviews== There have been a number of reviews for ''Rhythm of Structure'': * A paper covering the ''Knotting Mathematics and Art: Conference in Low Dimensional Topology and Mathematical Art'' at [[University of South Florida]] in November 2007 appeared in the ''Journal of Mathematics and Arts''.<ref name="knottingpaper" /> * At the Bowery Poetry Club show, Sol Lewitt and Adrian Piper's exhibition with featured response by Mark Strand was review in ''Art in America'' by John Reed in March 2010.<ref name="artistsdothemath" /> * ''The Cartesian MathArt Hive'' piece featured in the ''Rhythm of Structure: Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection'' (2009–10) exhibition was covered by a journal paper, April 2010, in the ''Journal of Mathematics and Arts''.<ref name="cartesianmathhivepaper" /> * Gregory Vincent St. Thomasino featured an element of the ''Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection'' poetry presentation his blog in April 2010.<ref name="GregoryVincentStThomasino" /> * ''Sarasota Herald Tribune'' writer Marty Fugate previewed the Ringling College of Art and Design exhibition at Selby Gallery and ''Rhythm of Structure'' film which screened at the Sarasota Film Festival in April 2012.<ref name="saratosaheraldtribune" /> * The Antioch College showing of ''Rhythm of Structure'' was covered in April 2012 by the Jane A. Black for the ''[[Dayton City Paper]]''.<ref name="saratosaheraldtribune"/> * SQR Magazine reviewed ''The Square Root of Love'', featured in the ''Rhythm of Structure: Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection'' (2009–10) exhibition , at the Bowery Poetry Club in April 2012.<ref name="SQR Magazine"/>
==See also== * [[Journal of Mathematics and the Arts]] * [[The Bridges Organization]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=40em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.rhythmofstructure.com/}} * ''[http://knotart.cas.usf.edu/graphicSite/exhibition.html Rhythm of Structure: Beyond the Mathematics online exhibition]'' * ''[https://issuu.com/mathartist/docs/testcata1 Rhythm of Structure: Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection catalog]'' * ''[https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~sequin/ART/RythmOfStructure/index.html Rhythm of Structure: Mathematics, Art and Poetic Reflection select pictures of works]''
